story:
A big thank you for your interest in our toy exchange community! Please join us today in building this important parent resource.  Your contribution really matters. It will help to get it going so families like yours can start exchanging toys and games as soon as possible.  Just click on a Perk on the right sidebar of this page to contribute AND get a membership at the same time. And please, SPREAD THE WORD!

A little bit about me

I live in Oakland, California and have two young children who LOVE toys.  We have lots of them.  Too many in my opinion.  But my kids don't think so.  They want more. And more. And more.

How do I satisfy my kids' insatiable appetite for fun new toys?  And not spend thirty percent of our income doing it? Or constantly have to offload toys at the local donation station, never knowing whether they actually make it into the hands of other families, or maybe just end up in a landfill or floating around in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch?

An online toy recycling program, of course, TOY-CYCLE.ORG.

How it works

Imagine a sunny Saturday afternoon. A beautiful day to be outside. But you are diligently working to clear the clutter of toys from the living room floor, your kid's bedroom and the hall closet. I mean, seriously, you can barely see the floor! You locate toys your child hasn't played with since kindergarten. Never mind she is in 3rd grade now. What can you do? Get online and offer those toys up to your local TOY-CYCLE.ORG group. Another family wants them. You connect and make arrangements for that family to get the toys from you.  

Now, imagine the following Saturday. You see a post for a toy or game your entire family would love.  You respond to the posting family. Woohoo, it turns out they live just eight blocks from you!  You go pick it up, bring it home, thrill your kids.  No shipping, no packaging, no money changing hands.  

When you sign up for TOY-CYCLE.ORG, you can try out the site for the first 60 days free.  If it works for you, you'll be asked to pay a small annual membership fee of $12 to help defray the costs of the site's operation and maintenance. That's it.  $12 a year. There is no charge for exchanging toys and games.  Your home group will include families within about a five-mile radius of where you live.  You can also sign up to get notifications from other nearby groups if you choose.

Sound great?  I think so too.  And I would like to ask for your help in making it happen. 

You can contribute to this Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign AND at the same time get a 1-year, 3-year or even lifetime membership to TOY-CYCLE.ORG!  As soon as a local user group launches in your location, you'll be able to start exchanging toys and games. Take a look at the Perks listed in the right sidebar of this page and select the one that works best for you.

Other Important Ways You Can Help

Make a lot of NOISE about our campaign! Endorse it resoundingly. Make use of the sharing tools on this page. Like it. Share it. Pin it. Tweet it. Retweet it. Email it to your friends, family, moms' groups, dads' groups, co-workers, neighbors. Talk our campaign up at school drop-off and pick-up, at play-dates, while in line at the grocery store! Did I say make noise? MAKE NOISE! Crowdfunding takes a crowd. Please don't be shy. Share your enthusiasm. 

Your support is truly appreciated. Thank you for working with me to make this vision a reality!

Use of Funds

Our small but exceedingly enthusiastic team has done a lot of legwork in dealing with the preliminaries.  We have a development team ready to start building the site. We need $9,300 to get TOY-CYCLE.ORG up and running.  We will use these funds for:

  1. Complete custom development of a community website that allows families to exchange used toys and games in locations across the country–$7,600
  2. Website design $700
  3. Fundamentals. That includes things like domain registration, site hosting, website launch and other administrative costs–$1,000

Toys and Our Environment

Americans spend more than $20 billion on toys annually. That's a lot of toys and a lot of packaging. Fully one-third of municipal trash in the U.S. is packaging. While most of that is food packaging, a good percentage is toy packaging.  We're talking about those unbelievably annoying plastic, mini-fortresses that are so hard to open, you've occasionally considered a jackhammer might be in order.  Frequently toy packaging is made from plastics that have a low recycle rate, as not all municipalities include them in their recycling programs. So that plastic ends up in landfills where it slowly decomposes over a long period of time, hundreds, even thousands of years. Or even if the packaging is not plastic, it might be cardboard sourced from a rainforest in Indonesia, as Greenpeace discovered in 2011, when investigating the packaging Barbie dolls are sold in. All that packaging uses precious resources and has a tremendous ecological impact.

Toys and Our Health

Chemicals in the most common packaging plastics have been linked to numerous health problems including cancers, altered immune function, impaired brain and neurological functions, adult-onset diabetes, obesity, and others.

Want an easy way to say no to all the packaging? Give and get USED toys through TOY-CYCLE.ORG.  It's the right choice.

Save money, reduce clutter, spare the earth.

FAQ

When will I be able to start exchanging toys on TOY-CYCLE.ORG? Our projected launch period is Spring of 2017.  User groups throughout the US will be added continually thereafter. You will be able to exchange toys as soon as a user group is open in your location. 

What types of toys can I find on TOY-CYCLE.ORG? The types of toys and games are really only limited by what other member families choose to give. You might find dolls, toy trucks, wooden blocks, rattles, riding toys, learning toys, board games for all ages, puzzles, card games, lego sets, action figures, stuffed animals, science sets, craft kits, poker chips, etc.  If it's a toy or a game, it can be exchanged on TOY-CYCLE.ORG.

Are there different age groups? You will be able to filter by age.  Age 0-3, Age 4-8 and Age 9 Up. You can select to receive notifications for as many age ranges as you choose.

How big are the user groups? While this will depend on the location, we will endeavor to keep the geographic size of the user group reasonably small so that families do not have to travel far to get toys and games.  For a small town, this may mean just one user group. For a larger city or metropolitan area, there will be several user groups. As an example, in the San Francisco East Bay, there will be as many as a dozen user groups. At least two for Oakland, two for Berkeley, one for Emeryville, one for Alameda, one for San Leandro, one for Albany, one for El Cerrito, and so on.

Can I belong to more than one group? Your home group will be determined by the zip code of your residence address. You will be able to post toys and games to that group.  You can receive notifications from as many groups as you choose.  So for example, a Manhattan resident's home group may be Lower Manhattan.  That member can choose to receive notifications and get toys from groups in Upper Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Hoboken and Jersy City, or any other nearby groups. 

Will I get the 60-day free trial if I contribute now? If you choose one of the perks in the right sidebar, you will get an additional 60 days added to your annual membership.  Your membership will begin once a user group has launched in your location.

If you have any other questions, please use the Ask a Question link near the top right side of this page or contact us at info@toy-cycle.org.  We will respond to you directly and also update this FAQ section with any new questions and answers throughout the campaign.

Again THANK YOU for joining us in building this fantastic toy exchange community. We truly appreciate your contribution!

story:
Moi Social

Learning is a game in which kids grow a unique tree as they read and learn new concepts

Send an email to learning@growmoi.com to register & play

We believe we can leverage the power of technology to introduce an entire generation to the world of interconnected learning

This is how we got here:

We need your help to finish the final 5 modules of the game and make it as beautiful and crisp as it can be. Everything has already been designed and is ready to be put together by our team of developers

Every Backer gets a copy of Moi Social Learning where anyone can:

  •  Discover the full tree of knowledge
  • Share results with friends & family
  • Learn at their own pace
  • Get connected to learners from all over the world

We started  testing our beta in September of this year, with excellent results

But we still need to refine the final details before we can fully open our experience to the public

This is the reason we need your help. Only through this Indiegogo campaign, you can buy Moi Social Learning for one of the kids in your life AND also give one to a kid who needs it for only $10. In this way, we aim to ensure the means to have Moi Social Learning reach thousands of kids worldwide

We invite everyone to participate in any way you can. If you can't buy Moi, please share this campaign with #Moi1x1 with those you care about. We'll be enormously grateful. If you feel really inspired, go ahead and record a short vid of yourself telling everybody what you think of our project with #Moi1x1 

Please contact us with any questions: learning@growmoi.com

story:
The days of "I just don't get politics" are over.

Women are stepping into the arena in droves, more fired up than ever before.

 

 

It's our time.

From arguing with Grandpa at Thanksgiving to running for office and everything in between, Get Politics 101 is designed to equip women with knowledge and confidence to stand in the conversation in new ways. The course will include:

  • an exploration of women's "Politics Mindset" and how to crush perceived obstacles
  • a solid foundation in government and politics
  • a guide to choosing the right action for you and shutting out the noise
     

 

 

When politics meets comedy, something powerful happens.

Our shoulders relax. Through cry-laugh tears, we see things more clearly.

We’re bringing that power to online education for the first time ever!

We’re casting a dynamic group of women experts and comedians from the amazing talent pool of NYC for a brand new kind of online course. It will be informative, engaging, and entertaining like your favorite comedy talk show.

We need to reach as many women as possible in a brand new way without to-do-lists or judgement. This is how we will move the needle. 

 

We need Get Politics 101 to happen now.

Here's what we need to shoot the pilot:

Production: $14,700

Writing, Direction and Talent: $7,300

Cameras/Lights: $4,350

Location: $1,570

Art and Post Production: $9,250

Total being raised: $37,170

Every amount counts! Every contribution supports us and moves us towards our goal. Poli-Anna needs to happen. If you agree, contribute any amount you can. Your support means the world to us and it is bringing our pilot video closer to reality.

 

Get on board.

We're looking for the right partners who share our values and believe in our mission. If you're a business, this is a great time to put your name on this important project. Just to name a few ideas:

  • Sponsored content behind the scenes: casting comedians and experts, making the pilot
  • Product placement or mention in the pilot video
  • Co-branded merchandise / sponsored events

Let's grab coffee and discuss your custom sponsorship perk or package! We'll use our advertising expertise to collaborate with you on a unique creative strategy. Contact Evan at go.polianna@gmail.com.

 

    Tweet it out.

    Every time you share a post or forward an email, we are one step closer to getting the large-scale attention and funding we need. Besides contributing financially, you can help in the following ways:

    • Take our quick survey
    • Join our mailing list
    • Share this campaign with your community! Paste this link into your Facebook post or tweet: https://igg.me/at/poli-anna
       

    poli-anna.com  //  go.polianna@gmail.com

story:
WHO WE ARE

Blue Box Alliance is a group of theater professionals and amateurs comprised of Jeremy Wheeler, J. M. Harkness, Kylo Christensen, Ian Hilden, and Kristen Sullivan.   BBA's founder, Jeremy Wheeler, is a teacher in the public education system in eastern Kentucky.  Every day he sees the devastating effects bullying has on students.  Jeremy is also a zealous fan of Doctor Who and a film actor.  One day Jeremy decided to merge his love for performance and teaching, thus Blue Box Alliance was formed.   Together, the cast and crew of Blue Box Alliance are avid Doctor Who fans united to blast bullying!

To learn more about us, visit the link below:

https://blueboxalliance.wordpress.com/about/​ 

WHAT WE (PLAN TO) DO

We will cosplay as various incarnations of Doctor Who and his companions and allies.  It is our vision is to visit schools, libraries, and birthday parties to educate children of all ages about the effects of bullying through a Doctor Who themed show.  Our vision is also to visit children in hospitals, and other care facilities to offer smiles and happiness as Doctor Who performers.

For a full list of services we hope to employ, please visit the following link:

 http://blueboxalliance.wordpress.com/services/

 

 

WHY WE ARE RAISING MONEY

The cost to construct sets, build props, buy costumes, engineer robotics, and purchase advertising and marketing material are beyond our personal means.   Funds raised through IndieGoGo will go to help us purchase materials to build a life-sized replica TARDIS, employ a prop and costume maker to design and construct a screen accurate Cyberman costume, and also a fully functioning robotic K9 (robot dog).  Funds will also be used to purchase professional costumes, accessories, business cards, posters, postcards, t-shirts, and wristbands -- most of which are perks for donating to our cause.

Together we can blast bullying in a fun and exciting way!

 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN
story_txt: WHO WE AREBlue Box Alliance is a group of theater professionals and amateurs comprised of Jeremy Wheeler, J. M. Harkness, Kylo Christensen, Ian Hilden, and Kristen Sullivan.   BBA's founder, Jeremy Wheeler, is a teacher in the public education system in eastern Kentucky.  Every day he sees the devastating effects bullying has on students.  Jeremy is also a zealous fan of Doctor Who and a film actor.  One day Jeremy decided to merge his love for performance and teaching, thus Blue Box Alliance was formed.   Together, the cast and crew of Blue Box Alliance are avid Doctor Who fans united to blast bullying!To learn more about us, visit the link below:https://blueboxalliance.wordpress.com/about/​ WHAT WE (PLAN TO) DOWe will cosplay as various incarnations of Doctor Who and his companions and allies.  It is our vision is to visit schools, libraries, and birthday parties to educate children of all ages about the effects of bullying through a Doctor Who themed show.  Our vision is also to visit children in hospitals, and other care facilities to offer smiles and happiness as Doctor Who performers.For a full list of services we hope to employ, please visit the following link: http://blueboxalliance.wordpress.com/services/  WHY WE ARE RAISING MONEYThe cost to construct sets, build props, buy costumes, engineer robotics, and purchase advertising and marketing material are beyond our personal means.   Funds raised through IndieGoGo will go to help us purchase materials to build a life-sized replica TARDIS, employ a prop and costume maker to design and construct a screen accurate Cyberman costume, and also a fully functioning robotic K9 (robot dog).  Funds will also be used to purchase professional costumes, accessories, business cards, posters, postcards, t-shirts, and wristbands -- most of which are perks for donating to our cause.Together we can blast bullying in a fun and exciting way! BUDGET BREAKDOWN

story:
Have you ever woken up to see the sunrise over desert badlands, or held a mosasaur fossil in your hand that you excavated yourself? For students fascinated by earth and life science, getting into the field can be an invaluable growth and learning opportunity. Hands-on experience documenting wildlife, exploring rock formations, and excavating fossils builds skills, knowledge, and character, all invaluable for a budding naturalist. My goal is to expand the availability of the Sternberg Science Camps programs to more students from underprivileged backgrounds.

Participating in outdoor science education programs was an immensely important part of my teenage years. The growth I underwent in those programs learning about field paleontology continues to astound me. With that growth came opportunity, and a place to belong: paid jobs to build my resume, a path in college, lifelong friends with shared interests in science, and mentors that helped me reach my goals. I would simply not be who or where I am now, working as professional science educator and part-time researcher, without attending those programs in my youth.

Without the financial aid I received from the camp program, I would never have been able to attend in the first place.

Now, I run my own outdoor science education camps program, and I am working to create the same opportunities for a new generation of students driven by excitement and curiosity.

I am campaigning to raise funds for student scholarships to attend the Sternberg Museum Science Camps program I run in western Kansas. I founded this program in 2014, to bring the kinds of transformative experiences I had to students who until now have had little access to such opportunities. My goal is to raise $13,000 for financial aid, to help economically disadvantaged students pursue their passions in earth and life science.
 

 

The second half of this fundraiser is to jump start the Nature Connect program, to bring field earth and life science lessons and activities to classrooms across the country, free of any charge to schools, teachers, or students. These lessons and activities will be built around photos, videos, and data collected by students in the Sternberg Science Camps during field programs. I will use these materials to create Next Generation Science Standard-aligned classroom materials. (This is crucial, as it allows teachers to justify using the lessons without putting their students behind on standardized test prep.) The lesson activities are key, and will introduce students to field science techniques and practices while hitting concept benchmarks during interactive exercises. All for free for educators to use in their classrooms, and accessible with a simple download of a module that includes media, data, instructions, rubrics, content outlines, and implementation support for the lesson+activity. I want to make it as easy as possible for classroom science educators to bring these engaging, exciting classroom lessons to their students, irrespective of the school's finances. As a bonus, the students engage with science concepts in simulation of field research activities conducted by professional scientists.  

In order to collect the photos, videos, and data needed to build the Nature Connect classroom lesson modules, I need to boost the quality of field equipment used by camps students in the field. To do this, my goal is to raise $13,000 for field equipment.Camps students receive focused training on the use of all equipment used to collect data and media. Double education bonus! See just below for a list of what I'm planning to add to the camps field gear armory, to facilitate the Nature Connect program.

Why field sciences?

Our understanding of how our planet functions is built on field research, exploring and answering questions in the earth and life sciences. In the face of a changing planet, we need as many excited young people as possible trained in the basics of field work, science, and natural history. Beyond training a new generation of future scientists, I want to recruit, train, and educate students who go on to be business owners, political leaders, lawyers, teachers, parents of their own children, and science-literate members of society with an informed appreciation for natural sciences. This means making impactful, experiential education opportunities available as widely as possible, in ways that will engage student’s attention, and inspire them to start asking their own questions. This starts with removing financial barriers to opportunity.

Nature-Based Experiential Learning, For All

Not all students have easy access to science learning opportunities. Low income students in urban and rural schools face some of the toughest challenges in pursuing their interests in science. A combination of lacking opportunities and economic resources can box out entire demographics of talented, driven students anxious to explore. A 2010 cooperative study by the Census Bureau, US Department of Education, and National Center For Education Statistics found the highest concentrations of youth living in poverty to be urban and rural in the West, Midwest, and South. Economically disadvantaged schools in urban and rural settings typically suffer from a sharp lack of resources for teachers to engage students in natural sciences in the classroom.

 

Here, I see two problems that can be approached simultaneously:
1) Socioeconomically disadvantaged students looking for opportunities to pursue interests in earth and life science.

2) Resource-strapped schools lacking the ability to provide students with high quality, engaging classroom lessons and content to get students excited about science while complying with Next Generation Science Standard guidelines.  


A Solution to Kindle Interest in Nature, and Science

Engaging students from underserved rural and urban communities, and providing them with the knowledge, confidence, and informational resources to pursue their interests in science and continue their education, are my biggest driving forces in operating these camp programs.

Your contribution will help train a new, diverse generation of earth and life science students in the places that need these resources the most.

 

 

Your contribution will help us:

Purchase the equipment we need to create dynamic science lessons and activities, and train camps students in the use of professional-quality field equipment.

 

Before factoring in any education direct-purchase discounts (which many companies do), this equipment accounts $13,000, half of my $26,000 fundraising goal.

Students will be trained in the use and maintenance of all equipment purchased during respective camp programs. This training is a central part of the camps. Students leave with functional skills relevant to field science in addition to greater knowledge of science concepts. In using this equipment, students will help gather materials I will use to build the Nature Connect classroom modules.

The other $13,000 in my fundraising goal will go towards financial aid scholarships to camps students. These scholarships are hugely important in insuring as many students excited about earth and life sciences can attend as possible.

As our recruiting efforts and number of enrollments have grown, so have requests for needed financial assistance. Over the past three years, I have been able to provide over $8,000 in financial aid to students via donations. As the camps program grows and becomes more widely known, the need for financial aid funds will only increase. This $13,000 will be used to cover requests in 2017, and boost funds for 2018.

 

 

If we exceed our goal:

  • We will be able to provide more scholarships for larger amounts to student applicants!
  • More kids excited about earth and life science get to join the Sternberg Science Camps trips!
  • We will have more students in our field teams, allowing us to cover more ground, collect more media and data for the Nature Connect lessons and activities I will build.


If we do not reach our goal:

  • We won’t be able to provide as much financial as I estimate we’ll need in 2017.
  • We won’t be able to get all of the equipment necessary to create the best classroom programs possible with Nature Connect.
  • We will also not be able to provide as robust equipment use training to camps students out in the field.
 

Representation disparities still exist in the sciences. By growing our financial aid funding pool, the Sternberg Museum Science Camps staff will be able to more actively recruit gifted students excited about science to come participate, and interact with other students that share their interests. This group bonding aspect has been one of the strongest pieces of positive feedback camps staff has received from students and parents.

Your donation can help us change a summer, change a year, change the life of a student. In just three years since starting our programs, we have received a tremendous outpouring of positive feedback from parents and students.

Feedback from students.
Feedback from parents.

Fighting for student opportunity

Understanding of geology, paleontology, and field biology are the keys to the past, present, and future of our planet. Natural history studies have been slowly fading out of our classrooms and cultural awareness for decades, and we are the worse for it. Through the Nature Connect program, I want to give students a jolt of excitement for natural history, observation, and inquiry. We cannot take every student to the Chiricahua Mountains, or cloud forest of Ecuador to explore wildlife. Nor can we take every student to the chalk beds of Kansas to explore the fossils and geology of the ancient sea. With your help, we can begin work to bring some of those experiences to students anywhere in the country.

I will use stimulating, vibrant lessons and activities that draw straight from our field camp programs to drive observation, inquiry, and engagement with science through the spectacle of the natural world. But I can’t do it without your help.

  • https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/artful-amoeba/natural-history-is-dying-and-we-are-all-the-losers/
  • biographic.com/posts/sto/remembering-the-stories-of-nature
     

 

  • We are a small museum in a very low density population area, meaning this crowdfund is heavily reliant on word of mouth and social media extending outside our home-region.
  • The success of Nature Connect is predicated on teachers buying in to using the lessons.

Addressing Risks and Challenges

  • This is the second crowdfund I have run. (The first was to start the Sternberg Science Camps in 2014.) I learned a lot from the experience, and my 2.5 years on the job since.
  • Despite being small, we have a skilled, dedicated staff devoted to accessible science education opportunities for all students.
  • Exercising connections to professional educator organizations, and direct connections to classrooms teachers, I will pilot the Nature Connect programs in a small set of initial classrooms, and work out from there. Widespread use of the lesson modules will not happen over night, but I'm confident that with a high quality product, the program will sell itself. Being free helps too!
  • As word spreads throughout the region and I get better at marketing, student enrollments have steadily increased. Since 2014, enrollment in the Sternberg Science Camps has tripled. Being able to recruit economically disadvantaged students with the confidence of scholarship support will be invaluable in this effort.

 


My name is David Levering. I have nearly two full years of combined time spent in the field with youth doing experiential science education programs. I have been a certified Wilderness First Responder for going on seven years. I have first-hand experience and coursework in wilderness safety, skills, and best practices.

My education includes a Bachelors of Science degree in geology from University of Oregon, and a Masters of Science degree in zoology from Oklahoma State University. At both institutions, my studies emphasized vertebrate paleontology, paleoecology, and principles of evolution and ecology in modern systems.

These experiential education programs are a result of almost a decade of planning, framing, cooperation, relationship-building, setting goals and reaching them. I'm just getting started, and hope you will join me in my effort to bring exciting earth and life science education experiences to as many students as possible. 

 

Do you have natural history science programs and scholarships for younger kids?
We do! We offer nine single-day programs about natural sciences for 1st-5th grades during the summer, as part of the Sternberg Museum Science Camps.

Why experiential education?
Learning by doing is the absolute soundest method of teaching outdoor and field science skills. Students in the field programs are guided through the use of tools and techniques, with the goal of them being able to work proficiently at basic fieldwork tasks by the end of the program. Feedback from students shows that it works. Returners, coming back a year later, retain functional knowledge of skills and procedures, demonstrate increased competence and confidence, and show greater initiative during field work and during camp tasks (setting up and breaking camp, loading vehicles, cooking meals, etc).

Why base the Nature Connect activities and lessons on the Next Generation Science Standards?
In order to justify using the lessons to administrators, and to parents, educators need to know they will not be getting behind on preparing their students for standardized tests required each year. My goal is to work with the standards to create lessons and activities that teachers will use without anxiety over getting behind schedule. The Nature Connect classroom modules will serve as standards-congruent learning experiences for students with bonus-added material: media and data pulled straight from the field to engage them with content standards, and give them a glimpse at how science actually gets done in the field.

Are all the Nature Connect activities digital? What about schools that don’t have enough computers for all their students?
While all of the activity and lesson materials will be made available online, not all will require every student to have access to a computer. We will be working with teachers to find cost-effective, efficient solutions to resource deficiencies without sacrificing impact or educational content of the Nature Connect materials.

Are you working with other scientists or educators on this project?
Absolutely! While my background is pretty well-rounded, I definitely don’t have universal expertise in field work or pedagogy. I have a network of other professional educators and scientists who contribute their time as seasonal staff for the field programs, or serve as informal consultants. The core staff will grow with the field and Nature Connect programs as needed.

What equipment will you be purchasing?
I will be purchasing digital cameras, camera lenses, motion-detecting camera traps, a directional parabolic microphone kit, binoculars, Brunton geologic surveying compasses, and headlamps. All equipment will be used in the summer field programs. Students will be trained in the use and maintenance of the equipment by instructional staff in the field. I have included a bullet-point list above, in the What We Need & What You Get section.

IMPACT

  1. ​Improve 12 children’s writing, research skills and public speaking  through weekly writing assignments 
  2. Increase 12 children's cultural awareness by learning about the principles of Kwanza
  3. Develop 12 children's knowledge and exposure in the following STEM areas:
  • Chemistry
  • Renewable energy
  • Water Purification
  • Volcanoes
  • Weather Stations


    If you are unable to donate, but would still like to make a contribution, please click here for our amazon wish list.

story:
Our Story

For over 20 years we’ve been a valuable resource in the tristate area, through the teaching of time honored ancestral and life enhancing skills to individuals, families, communities, organizations and businesses. However, even though there’s been overwhelming demand for additional skills training, we have not been able to provide expanded course offerings due to restrictions of not having our own land.

We need your support to build a place where children can learn and grow, and adults can explore and regain balance. A place that recognizes the importance of reconnecting with nature. A place that’s only an hour from the city, yet a world away.

We believe that being prepared is being responsible. Self-sufficiency and preparedness are crucial skills that are needed to meet the many challenges of life. Please join us in building a place for the people of today and the children of tomorrow.

 

                                           

Founder of Mountain Scout Survival School, Shane Hobel, has always been a student of nature and martial arts since very early childhood. He has dedicated himself to learning and applying primitive/ancestral skills, and this became the foundation for his interest and development of his expertise. 

Working under the teachings of many native elders, he has truly developed his wilderness skills and has immersed himself in the writings, practices and philosophy of the native scout.

He is one of five members of Tom Brown Jr.'s elite Tracker Search and Forensic Investigation Team. Shane is also the wilderness survival and tracker expert featured on CNN, CBS, NBC, FOX, Inside Edition, WPIX 11 and Cablevision. He has also appeared on the History Channel, National Geographic, Mansome, The New York Times and The New Yorker, as well as prominent regional newspapers, magazines, radio interviews and countless media.

 

What You Are Funding

The Mountain Scout Earth School will open in phases as the different sections of the land and property are developed, eventually leading to greatly expanded class offerings, and operating as a fully functioning example of primitive to modern lifestyles being in harmony with the environment.

The future of Mountain Scout Earth School will provide a multitude of programs, classes, lectures and camps. We will first begin by continuing to teach the primitive and wilderness survival and urban classes. 

In honor of our fallen warrior brother Clark Fitzgerald, we will build out the wilderness area and name it after him 'Camp Clark - A Place for the Wild'

An overview of the branches we will offer:

  • Camp Clark -- A Place for the Wild, and Children's camp
  • Youth Summer and After School Programs, Mentorship and Internship Programs (Primary School to College)
  • Archery, Basketry, Weaving, Flintknapping
  • Corporate Training, Team Building
  • First Aid Certification courses, CPR & WFR
  • Military and Law Enforcement Training, Search and Rescue Team curriculum’s
  • Veteran support services
  • Healing Center, Retreat Center, Health and Wellbeing Programs; Yoga and Martial Arts
  • Ceremonial Training with Elders, Tribal Outreach and Story Telling
  • Sustainable Agriculture, Permaculture, Forest Farming, Medicinal and Edible Teaching Gardens
  • Sustainable Land and Property Development -- Net Zero/Net Positive Energy Facilities, Eco Village
  • Outdoor Adventure Courses

Aerial map

We have a dedicated, passionate and driven team ready to share knowledge and support you on your journey. We have been creating a school where people can come together and learn how to truly take care of themselves and their environments.

 

Cost Breakdown

  • The first $150,000 – Helps with legal and closing costs so we can begin teaching on-site immediately in Spring/Summer 2017
  • The second installment of $150,000.00 -- Helps with equipment,  structural repair costs, renovations to comply with building codes, building further teaching sites, offsets professional fees (architect, engineer and contractors)

 

Perks and Rewards

With your support of $10 and over, we will enter you in our raffle being drawn on the last day of our campaign!  5 winners will be chosen and prizes will be sent within a month.  Items that are being raffled off and the grand prize will be announced soon -- Stay Tuned for updates!

In addition to being entered into the raffle drawing, here are some perks to thank you for your support: 

  • $25  - 10% credit towards class
  • $50.00 – Half Day Class
  • $99.00 – Full Day Class
  • $299.00 – Wilderness Weekend
  • $500.00 – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, and a T-shirt
  • $1,000.00 – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, and T-shirts for 2
  • $5,000.00 – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, and T-shirts for 2, a Survival Starter Gear Bag, and a Private Phone Consultation with Shane
  • $10,000.00+ – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, T-shirts, and Survival Starter Gear Bags for 2, and an Private In-Person Consultation with Shane
  •  

Risks Challenges and Opportunities

In the different locations in the cities and around the parks there are many restrictions that cause the areas to be not ideal locations for Mountain Scout Survival School to evolve into Mountain Scout Earth School. It’s more important than ever to reach people with survival skills.

This is an amazing opportunity we don’t want to miss! It has taken Mountain Scout Survival School ten years to find land that can accommodate its vision.

It is our hope in that providing a place to nurture the relationships we have with nature around us, we can connect people of all walks of life back into balance and in harmony.

 

FAQ

Where is it? 

Only an hour from the city, yet a world away. Tucked beautifully away in Hopewell Junction. Between Beacon and Fishkill, off the Taconic State Parkway and I-84. It is easily accessible by the Metro North.

Who is it open to?  

Children 9 & under accompanied by parent & Ages 9 and up

Is there a Volunteer program?

Yes! There are many opportunities, please send us an email at mt.scoutsurvival@gmail.com

How else can I get involved?

Please see our full events and calendar or stop by our  Beacon office. http://mtnscoutsurvival.com/
story_txt:
Our Story
For over 20 years we’ve been a valuable resource in the tristate area, through the teaching of time honored ancestral and life enhancing skills to individuals, families, communities, organizations and businesses. However, even though there’s been overwhelming demand for additional skills training, we have not been able to provide expanded course offerings due to restrictions of not having our own land.
We need your support to build a place where children can learn and grow, and adults can explore and regain balance. A place that recognizes the importance of reconnecting with nature. A place that’s only an hour from the city, yet a world away.
We believe that being prepared is being responsible. Self-sufficiency and preparedness are crucial skills that are needed to meet the many challenges of life. Please join us in building a place for the people of today and the children of tomorrow.
 
                                           
Founder of Mountain Scout Survival School, Shane Hobel, has always been a student of nature and martial arts since very early childhood. He has dedicated himself to learning and applying primitive/ancestral skills, and this became the foundation for his interest and development of his expertise. 
Working under the teachings of many native elders, he has truly developed his wilderness skills and has immersed himself in the writings, practices and philosophy of the native scout.
He is one of five members of Tom Brown Jr.'s elite Tracker Search and Forensic Investigation Team. Shane is also the wilderness survival and tracker expert featured on CNN, CBS, NBC, FOX, Inside Edition, WPIX 11 and Cablevision. He has also appeared on the History Channel, National Geographic, Mansome, The New York Times and The New Yorker, as well as prominent regional newspapers, magazines, radio interviews and countless media.
 
What You Are Funding
The Mountain Scout Earth School will open in phases as the different sections of the land and property are developed, eventually leading to greatly expanded class offerings, and operating as a fully functioning example of primitive to modern lifestyles being in harmony with the environment.
The future of Mountain Scout Earth School will provide a multitude of programs, classes, lectures and camps. We will first begin by continuing to teach the primitive and wilderness survival and urban classes. 
In honor of our fallen warrior brother Clark Fitzgerald, we will build out the wilderness area and name it after him 'Camp Clark - A Place for the Wild'
An overview of the branches we will offer:

Camp Clark -- A Place for the Wild, and Children's camp
Youth Summer and After School Programs, Mentorship and Internship Programs (Primary School to College)
Archery, Basketry, Weaving, Flintknapping
Corporate Training, Team Building
First Aid Certification courses, CPR & WFR
Military and Law Enforcement Training, Search and Rescue Team curriculum’s
Veteran support services
Healing Center, Retreat Center, Health and Wellbeing Programs; Yoga and Martial Arts
Ceremonial Training with Elders, Tribal Outreach and Story Telling
Sustainable Agriculture, Permaculture, Forest Farming, Medicinal and Edible Teaching Gardens
Sustainable Land and Property Development -- Net Zero/Net Positive Energy Facilities, Eco Village
Outdoor Adventure Courses


Aerial map
We have a dedicated, passionate and driven team ready to share knowledge and support you on your journey. We have been creating a school where people can come together and learn how to truly take care of themselves and their environments.
 
Cost Breakdown

The first $150,000 – Helps with legal and closing costs so we can begin teaching on-site immediately in Spring/Summer 2017
The second installment of $150,000.00 -- Helps with equipment,  structural repair costs, renovations to comply with building codes, building further teaching sites, offsets professional fees (architect, engineer and contractors)

With your support of $10 and over, we will enter you in our raffle being drawn on the last day of our campaign!  5 winners will be chosen and prizes will be sent within a month.  Items that are being raffled off and the grand prize will be announced soon -- Stay Tuned for updates!

In addition to being entered into the raffle drawing, here are some perks to thank you for your support: 

$25  - 10% credit towards class
$50.00 – Half Day Class
$99.00 – Full Day Class
$299.00 – Wilderness Weekend
$500.00 – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, and a T-shirt
$1,000.00 – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, and T-shirts for 2
$5,000.00 – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, and T-shirts for 2, a Survival Starter Gear Bag, and a Private Phone Consultation with Shane
$10,000.00+ – Wilderness Weekend, Fire 1 and Tracking 1 Classes, T-shirts, and Survival Starter Gear Bags for 2, and an Private In-Person Consultation with Shane
 

Risks Challenges and Opportunities
In the different locations in the cities and around the parks there are many restrictions that cause the areas to be not ideal locations for Mountain Scout Survival School to evolve into Mountain Scout Earth School. It’s more important than ever to reach people with survival skills.
This is an amazing opportunity we don’t want to miss! It has taken Mountain Scout Survival School ten years to find land that can accommodate its vision.

story:
WHAT

Nadine's Kitchen is a pop-up restaurant where people's spirits will be raised by an earful of soulful, genre-bending music and a stomach-full of Southern-inspired yet decidedly Northwest-raised food fusion. The staff will consist of at-risk youth who want to be involved in the arts--culinary, fine and musical--but who have no family or community support. Mentors from the Seattle music, arts and foodie scenes will teach these young trainees valuable job skills and introduce them into networks that can support their ambitions. It's like a pop-up FareStart with hip live music.

WHY

As Grace continues to rise in her music career, she never forgets that she too was once at-risk. And with the fickleness of the music industry, a burgeoning music career can become at-risk in an instant. So she wants to leverage the level of visibility her music career has garnered around Seattle to develop a venture that creates a virtuous cycle of uplifting the less fortunate in a sustainable way while satiating urban foodies and continuing to build her growing fan base.

Risks and challenges

The main challenge is now raising the finances to facilitate Nadine's- the plans have been designed, the location is everywhere, and the team that will be built from this will be incredible. We just need the means to push it through.

The Impact

This will help launch Nadine's House- a art program for homeless youth. This program will provide training culinary skills and working the Kitchen learning how to prepare a meals then structuring time for the creative mind by partnering with artist in the local community, from writing to visual arts. With the main goal of providing a safe environment of housing and community. This program will facilitate meetings talking about the social justice and change that needs to occur for the creative mind.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share this 3 times in the next week and I will be forever grateful.

story:
Hello


My name is Baker Shabet, I am a 28 years-old, married and I have two daughters, I live in Palestine-Gaza that war-torn, I hold a bachelor's degree in Nursing and now I am working in children's hospital in Gaza, but unfortunately I get on very low salary about 300 $ monthly barely enough to buy food and milk for my kids.
Since my childhood, my goal is to complete my studies "Master Degree" abroad and since I graduated in 2010 and I have been trying to achieve this goal but unfortunately I could not because of the bad economic situation in Gaza.

You may ask me if I applied for other scholarships, I tried several times but they required higher GPA, although my average is 80.6% V. good degree.

 

I chose to study in Germany for several reasons:

First, the strength of its universities, especially in the field of health and nursing.

Secondly, for the tuition fees. Less than other universities 500 Euros per season and living costs for each month about 700 Euros

I need to cover the financial costs of studying and living for a master's degree.

German embassy requires me to have a bank account and has a balance of at least $ 12,000  to cover my living costs.

The amount that I need about $ 15,000 for a master's degree in Germany.

I love my specialty "Nursing" It's a wonderful humanitarian work it helps me in providing assistance to the sick children, I feel like I was reborn when giving treatment and care for children and getting out of the hospital in good health.

 

My Freinds.

You will help me, not only to reach my goal, but you will help a lot of children in need of care and treatment, and you will help them stay alive.

 

Thank you 

Baker Shabet

Gaza City, Palestine

mobile    00972599632528

https://www.facebook.com/snursekarime.shabet

story:
Due to the recent earthquake the Helambu valley has suffered a great damage. Some of the villages have been completely destroyed, death count is already in hundreds and rising. In one village alone the death toll has reached almost 100 and many people are homeless and without food. The HELP organization is focusing all their efforts in providing immediate help, water and food. 

Since some of the schools no longer exist and all of the communities suffered terrible losses it seems unlikely that any volunteers will be going to teach there this summer. We are still awaiting final decision on whether we will be able to go and help in any other way.

Your financial support is now more important than ever. The funds gathered here will go directly to emergency relief in Helambu. It is important to gather funds separately for this region as its remote localization and small industrial meaning place it at the end of a long list of places that receive support from central funds. 


It is no longer about providing a chance for a better life - it is about giving these people a chance to survive.


xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Studying at the University of Cambridge is always an amazing opportunity but being able to do so as a married couple made the experience a true privilege. Since we believe that all privileges should come with responsibilities, we want to be accountable for ours and have volunteered to teach in Nepal in June and July this year, as part of the HELP (Helambu Education and Livelihood Project - see www.help-nepal.org or our facebook page www.facebook.com/helphelambu with the official Letter of Support).

However, we are still students and it is very hard for us to cover all the costs of this project so even a £10 donation from each supporter would be a great help. All the money donated to this campaign will be used to help Nepalese schools. We are giving up the opportunity to trek in the Himalayas as part of the trip in order to be able to promise that this is a 100% charitable project.

We will be going to a school in the Helambu region where quality of education is very poor and resources scarce. Most of the schools don't even have running water, not to mention more education-specific luxuries like books or desks. Most of the teachers don't speak English (despite the fact that most subjects are taught in this language). Lessons are often limited to teachers reading from textbooks for 45mins. There is a great need for teacher training in all subjects, especially English.

Since the University of Cambridge has given us a lot of experience and training in teaching and training teachers we are in an excellent position to help. We are raising money to make the following changes during our stay in Nepal:

-  Teach the children: we want to show them that education can be fun and inspire them to learn.

-  Train the teachers: we want to share our methods and techniques to show them alternative ways of teaching.

-  Improve facilities: we want to provide the simplest things like building water pumps or the opportunity to use very basic teaching aids.

Where possible, we would also try to fund teacher's salaries and/or students scholarships from the raised funds.

We are able to afford only a small part of the funds required for this project despite being prepared to live and travel at cheapest possible rates. We will be working full time in very difficult conditions (described by previous volunteers as 'medieval': no running water, no electricity, no road access) in a 3rd world country with a completely different culture and language. We are happy to commit our time and effort but we need your financial help! Only together we can make a real difference.

You will be able to track our progress on our project page (where a list of donors will be posted). We will be grateful even for the smallest donations.


****************************************************************************

Możliwość studiowania na Uniwersytecie w Cambridge, szczególnie jako małżeństwo, jest dla nas niezwykłą szansą i ogromnym przywilejem. Wierzymy jednak, że każdy przywilej wiąże się  z obowiązkami i dlatego pragniemy wypełnić nasze, wyjeżdżając tego czerwca do Nepalu, jako wolontariusze projektu HELP (Helambu Education and Livelihood Project, tłum. Projekt Pomocy Edukacyjnej i Rozwojowej dla regionu Helambu, zobacz: www.help-nepal.org).

Niestety, jako że jesteśmy studentami, nie możemy sobie pozwolić na ufundowanie całego projektu. Dlatego też nawet £10 wsparcia ma dla nas znaczenie. Całość kwoty zebranej na tym portalu zostanie wykorzystana do pomocy nepalijskim szkołom. Zrezygnowaliśmy z możliwości wycieczek po Himalajach jako części wyjazdu, aby móc obiecać, że ten projekt jest w 100% charytatywny.

Jako wolontariusze wybieramy się do Helambu – regionu w Nepalu, gdzie poziom życia i edukacji jest tragiczny. Mieszkańcy nie mają dostępu do prądu czy nawet bieżącej wody. Brak jest podstawowych pomocy szkolnych takich jak ławki czy książki. Większość nauczycieli nie mówi po angielsku, mimo że uczą z podręczników w tym języku. Nauczanie w szkołach ogranicza się zwykle do odczytywania fragmentów podręcznika przez nauczyciela przez całą lekcję. Szkoły potrzebują sprzętu, a nauczyciele szkolenia.

Nasze doświadczenie w uczeniu i szkoleniu/zarządzaniu nauczycielami, zdobyte w Cambridge, daje nam możliwość niesienia pomocy w tym zakresie. W ramach projektu zamierzamy wykorzystać zebrane tutaj środki do:

- pomocy uczniom: chcemy pokazać im, że nauka może być ciekawa i wzbudzić w nich entuzjazm do nauki w szkole

- szkolenia nauczycieli: chcemy pomóc im rozwinąć ich zasób metod nauczania, pokazać im sposoby na efektywniejsze zaangażowanie uczniów

- ulepszenia lokalnej infrastruktury: w zależności od bieżących potrzeb szkoły może to być budowa pompy do wody pitnej, naprawa dachu czy zakup ławek do klas

- w miarę możliwości, z pozostałych środków chcielibyśmy także ufundować pensję dla dodatkowego nauczyciela lub/i stypendia dla uczniów.

Jesteśmy przygotowani na najniższe standardy podróżowania i pobytu. Będziemy pracować około 60 godzin tygodniowo w niezwykle trudnych warunkach (wolontariusze z poprzednich lat określają je mianem „średniowiecznych”), w kraju odległym zarówno geograficznie, jak i kulturowo. Wierzymy jednak, że warto  - każde dziecko zasługuje na dostęp do edukacji i możliwość rozwoju, niezależnie od stopnia zamożności rodziców. Pomóż nam uczynić świat troszkę lepszym i dać dzieciom z Helambu szansę na inne życie. Razem na pewno nam się uda.

Zapraszamy na naszą stronę projektu, gdzie można będzie śledzić nasze postępy, oglądać zdjęcia oraz zobaczyć pełną listę darczyńćów. Będziemy wdzięczni za każdą złotówkę!

lepszym i dać dzieciom z Helambu szansę na inne życie. Razem na pewno nam się uda.
Zapraszamy na naszą stronę projektu, gdzie można będzie śledzić nasze
postępy, oglądać zdjęcia oraz zobaczyć pełną listę darczyńćów. Będziemy
wdzięczni za każdą złotówkę!

story:
Hello, and thank you for visiting :)

Thank you for taking the time to consider helping me reach my goals and chase my dreams!

My Story:

Color is a part of my perception whether I am listening to or performing music, reading words on a page, or remembering dates and phone numbers. From my days in community college to UC Berkeley, I have aimed to learn more about synesthesia, a sensory processing difference that only 4% of the population can relate to (Robertson & Sagiv, 2004).

In September of 2013, I began working in the Palmer Lab for Visual Aesthetics at UC Berkeley as a subject and research apprentice. For the past year, I have been working with: the Palmer Lab, various authors and people in the academic community, and the GRAMMYs to recruit subjects for the project I have designed. After I collect my data, I will write a senior thesis to publish the results. Now, I have the opportunity to take my research to Utrecht University in the Netherlands to compare my data cross-culturally!


So....Why Utrecht, Netherlands?

The Netherlands is booming with research in synesthesia. I have identified a cardiologist and an academic researcher at the University of Amsterdam in which I will share my project with in hopes that I can collect data from the Dutch culture to compare with the American data I will collect when I return.


Goal for this Campaign

My trip in total will cost $6,000, and my goal is to raise $2,500 from this campaign. I received a $2,000 scholarship, and the rest of the cost I intend on covering through loans and a summer internship. These funds will help me book my flight, pay expenses of the program abroad, and travel around Europe to engage with others involved with synesthesia research. 


Why should I donate?

Synesthesia is changing the way the scientific community understands sensory processing as a whole, and I want to be at the forefront. Even conditions such as sensory processing disorders, learning disabilities, and anxiety have the potential to be seen differently if more is understood about the underworking components of cross-modal perception. Not only is it fascinating, but necessary to understand from this vantage point.

As a person with synesthesia, I am so excited to take my project abroad and submerge into the Dutch culture as I search for others with uncanny sensory experiences that can act as a catalyst in the field of clinical psychology.

story:
Every summer, Mongolian-American children from all over the U.S. gather at a unique summer camp in Indiana to learn about their cultural heritage. The children, ages 6 to 14, spend a week on the grounds of the Tibetan Mongolian Buddhist Culture Center in Bloomington, learning Mongolian language, dance, poetry, music, history and cultural values such as care for the environment. 


The camp was founded eight years ago by Mongolian language scholar Saruul-Erdene Myagmar and his wife Narantsetseg Tseveendulam, both language instructors at the U.S. State Department.  The camp is a project of their registered nonprofit, the Mongolian Cultural Center (contact info below), and it is a labor of love, aimed at nurturing community and cultural identity, as well as social skills, civic responsibility, and independence. 


The founders charge a modest $360 tuition for the weeklong sleepaway camp.  It has to be accessible to Mongolian immigrant families. In most cases, both parents work and with their limited income would otherwise not be able to afford such an opportunity for their children.  


The camp is at a turning point now. Costs are going up, and after dipping into their own savings to cover expenses,  founders Saruul and Nara have embarked on a public campaign to raise $8500 to keep the camp operating.   They need your help.  Please donate as little as $20 towards a successful, existing venture that is one of the only such efforts to pass down Mongolian culture among immigrant children in the U.S., strengthening the community and the self-confidence of these young, second-generation immigrants.  Take a look at the photos on this campaign site, to get a better look at what the camp is like! 


Here's how the $8500 would be spent: 
$4000 would go towards $500 stipends for the 8 instructors, including a cook (they have been volunteering until now, and still have to pay their own airfare, but stipends would ensure volunteers can keep coming). 
$2000 is for four $500 tuition/airfare subsidies for scholarship students.
$1500 is the Buddhist Center rental fee and utilities (water, electricity, gas) 
$500 for activity supplies (arts and crafts, soccer goals, basketball hoop) 
$500 for extra sleeping bags and light mattresses/futons


This $8500 would sustain a program that has an eight year track record of success, under thoughtful and caring leadership of two leading scholars of Mongolian language culture. This fundraising campaign would secure the camp for this summer, and allow the founders time to seek grant funding. 


The camp is operated under the founders' registered 501 (c) (3) non-profit, the Mongolian Cultural Center. All donations are tax deductible.  You can reach the Mongolian Cultural Center at info@mongolcc.org or 202-285-3422.

story:
The app that tackles dyslexia

Olivia Reader is the first app created from an idea of a child submitted in 2014 to the Super App Idea competition.

Sara Riches, a 12 y.o. girl from Putney (London) asked me if she could have an app to help her brother with reading. She was awarded the second prize but I decided to build her app first because 1 in 10 children in the UK have some level of dyslexia and could benefit from such an app straightaway.

A huge impact

Hundreds of thousands of children around the world can benefit from this app, and you can be part of it. Please help those children beat dyslexia.


The Google Chrome app

Right now I have developed the Google Chrome version. I need help completing the iOS version and making it free for everyone, for ever!

And you can help make it happen!

Challenges

Up to today, the Super App Idea Competition and the Google Chrome version of the Olivia Reader app were funded by me. Your contribution will speed up the development of the iOS version.

The competition rules state that the child who submits the idea gets 15% of the revenue generated by the app. Sarah Riches will be receiving 15% of the fund raised here because the app will never generate revenue again as it will be free and there will not be ads added into it.

Official Sponsors
Official Sponsors are anyone who donates £250 and over.
The app's splash page will display the official sponsors that donate £500 and over. The sponsor's logo can be linked to the sponsor's website, if a URL is provided by the sponsor.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please check the OliviaReader.com Website

story:
Short Summary

Let me start by saying,  thank you for visiting our campaign page and considering making a donation. This campaign is raising funds on behalf of  Liberian Council on Rural Poverty Alleviation's "Empower Education with Bicycles, Dewoein District” project 

In Dewoein, a province of Bomi County in Western Liberia, access to education and the opportunity to learn, something which every child must get regardless of their family background and community which they belong, is depressing for school children because of the lack of transportation means combined with long distances they have to walk  to school every day.

A little over 1,000 school children in the province walk 3-5 km to school every day. This cuts into their learning time and consequently affects school attendance and learning outcomes. In fact, sixty-five percent of these children do not go to school every day due to the long distances they have to trek to school every day. Parents of these children are unable to help them overcome the stress of walking this long distance because of poverty. Unlike you and I, they don't have any profession to earn sustainable income. Cassava farming and charcoal burning are the two main sources for income and  livelihood support.  In fact, their per capita income per day is less than 2USD.

This state of condition is preventing these school children in the province from getting an adequate quality basic  education, and will be ill-equipped to fight the cycle of poverty that affects their lives.

But we can change this - by offering hope and  the education they need and deserve.  Working together with you, we at Liberian Council on Rural Poverty Alleviation (LICORPA) want to provide them with a proven vehicle for educational empowerment: a bicycle. It’s proven that by providing school children who have   long distances to travel to school with bicycles - shortening their travel time by up to 70%- their school attendance and learning outcomes improve substantially. 

And that’s why we're obliged to launch this fundraising campaign, and we are appealing to you to join us and make your widow's might donations to this campaign .



 In fact, we are concerned that without your support, we won’t have the funds needed to help these school children.The project seeks the goal of improving access to education in Dewoein District, and its objective is to increase school attendance and learning outcomes from the low of 10% to the high of 20% at the end of the project.

Here are just few ways your donations will offer hope and education school children in Dewoein District need and deserve:

· Help school children overcome the stress of walking 3-5 km  to school every day.

·  Help school children get to school on time and effectively participate in class learning work.

·  Encourage school children to regularly attend school hereby increasing regular school attendance and improving learning outcomes substantially.

·  Help the children to become educated, fight the cycle of poverty, and contribute to the development of their communities. 

We are interested in this project for four main reasons. Firstly, we believe, access to quality basic education and the opportunity to learn, is something which every child must get regardless of their family background and community which they belong; secondly, we believe in the axiom that if you educate a child, you educate a community; thirdly, our children are our future and therefore, we must strive to protect that future; and fourthly, we have a responsibility to supporters like you to ensure that our philanthropic activities are highly impactful. This campaign reflects our commitment to all of these goals.

What We Need & What You Get

-US$15.00 will buy  1 repairing tool kit for 1 student;

-US$30.00 will buy 2 repairing tool kits for 2 students;

-US$65.00 will buy 2 repairing tool kits for 2 students and buy  spare parts  for 1 student for 1 year;

-US$130.00 will buy 2 repairing tool kits for students and  buy spare parts for 2 students for one year;

-US$165.00 will buy 1  bicycle, 1 repairing tool kit and  spare parts for  1 student for 1 year;

-US$330.00 will buy  2 bicycles, 2 repairing tool kits, and spare parts for 2 students for one year;

-US$495.00 will buy 3 bicycles, 3 repairing tool kits, and spare parts for 3 students for one year;

-US$660.00 will buy 4 bicycles, 4 repairing tool kits, and spare parts for 4 students for one year;

-US$825.00 will buy 5 bicycles, 5 repairing tool kits, spare parts for 5 students for one year;

US$990.00 will buy 6 bicycles, 6 repairing tool kits, spare parts for 6 students for one year ; and,

-US$1,155.00 will buy 7 bicycles, 7 repairing tool kits, and spare parts for 7 students for one year.

  

Although our funding goal is US$24,750.00, but the bare minimum to start the project is US$7,325.00. This will enable us to buy 44 bicycles, 44 repairing tool kits and spare parts for 44 students for one year. But if you help us to reach our funding goal of US$24,750.00, we will buy 150 bicycles, 150 repairing tool kits, spare parts for 150 students for one year, and support other general and administrative expenses of the project.  

We've perks which are unique for any amount you'll donate to this campaign. Below please find them listed:

-Thank You Letter+ newsletter........ $15.00;

- Share your posts on Facebook, Twitter, and Google+ for 1 month and receive newsletter......$30.00;

-Share your posts on Facebook, Twitter, Google+ for 2 months, receive beneficiaries progress report for 1 month+ newsletter for 1 quarter....$65.00;

-Share your posts with friends on Facebook,  followers on Twitter and  Google+ for 3 months,send you newsletter for 2 quarters, send you post card of a student ridding bicycle + beneficiaries progress report for 2 months......US$130.00;

-Share your posts with friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and  Google+ for 4 months, re-tweet your tweets for 1 months,  send you newsletter for 2 quarters, send you 1 LICORPA's T-Shirt and Cap, and send you  progress report for 2 months....US$165.00;

- Share your posts with our friends on Facebook,  followers on Twitter and Google+ for 5 months, send you newsletter for  3 quarters, send you  beneficiaries progress reports for 3 months, send you  digital album of project activities, and re-tweet your tweets for 2 months....US$330.00;


-Share all your posts with  friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and Google+ for 6 months,send you  beneficiaries progress reports for 4 months, send you video recording of project activities to watch with your family and say I made this to happen and re- tweet your tweets for 3 months,and send you beneficiaries progress report 7 months....US$495.00  

-Share all your posts with friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and Google+ for 7 months, re-tweet your tweets for 4 months, send a video recording of the project activities to watch with your family and  say I made this to happen, send you beneficiaries  progress report for 7 months,  and send you the caricature of a student ridding bicycles.....US$660.00;

-Share your posts for 8 months, re-tweet  your tweets for 5 months, send you  a carved wood map of Dewoein District,send you progress reports of beneficiaries for 7 months, send you video recording of project activities for you and your family to watch it and say I made this to happen, and send you  2 T-shirts and caps with a child riding a bicycle to school......US$825.00;

-Share  your posts with friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and Google+ for 9 months, re-tweets your tweets for 6 months, send you  newsletter for 4 quarters, send you LICORPA's full gear(2T-shirts, 2caps, and 2 rubber bracelets), send you beneficiaries progress reports for 8 months, send you  video recording of project activities to watch with your family and say I made this to happen, send you  a carved wood map of Bomi County, and send you  a caricature + novel of Bai T. Moore(Bai T. Moore was great Liberian poet, custodian of  Liberian culture, and a son of Dewoein District)......US$990.00; and,

-Share  your posts with friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and Google+ for 1 year, re-tweet your tweets for 1 year, send you  newsletter for 1 year, send you  beneficiaries progress for 1 academic year, send you  LICORPA's full gear(4 T-Shirts, 4 caps, and 4 bracelets), send you  video recording of project activities  to watch with your family and say I made it to happen, send you  an African gown, send you  a caricature of students ridding bicycles to school, and send you  a carved wood map of Dewoein District and Bai T. Moore + novel....US$1,155.00. 

Your decision to donate to our project, will put bicycles in the hands of school children in Dewoein District. Thank you.

The Impact

This project will help to promote regular school attendance and improve learning outcomes substantially. Moreover, it will help reduce poverty in the province because when the children are educated, they will overcome poverty and consequently  return to contribute to the development of their communities. 

Risks & Challenges

There are  inherent risks and challenges  in the implementation of the project, and they are: (1) some students might refuse to go to school after receiving the bicycles, (2) some students might sell the bicycles and convert the money into personal use, and (3) some students might decide to use the bicycles for rental purposes.   To avoid the occurrence of these, the following outlined measures will be adopted by LICORPA. (1)Community Monitoring Committees (CMC) will be setup. These committees in collaboration with LICORPA,  will select  students most in need and oversee the use of the bicycles, (2) Recipients will learn about bicycle safety and sign an agreement with LICORPA for regular school attendance, and (3) bi-weekly follow-up visitations will be made by LICORPA's Field Officer to get data on  regular school attendance and learning outcomes of beneficiaries. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you may have the desire to help financially, but the possibility does not exist. In this regards, you can help us by spreading the word to family members and friends in your network or even setup a fundraising page on your Facebook page and refer our campaign page link. This will highly be appreciated.

Liberian Council on Rural Poverty Alleviation or LICORPA is a registered not-for-profit organization with accreditation number 0153 from the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning of the Republic of Liberia.

LICORPA was established in May 2009 by band of committed Liberians with the objective of breaking barriers to opportunities for the rural poor, and it seeks the  vision of self-sufficient and self-reliant rural poor people who will work for the development of their persons and communities. LICORPA’s pursue a  mission of giving helping hands to the rural poor to work their way out of poverty and live a dignified and healthier life. Our program services include: (i) Education, (ii) Microfinance and (iii) Skills Training. These program services are designed to help the rural poor to overcome the dehumanizing effects of poverty.

Since its inception in May 2009, beneficiaries of LICORPA are now able to send more of their children to school, provide the next meal without untold sufferings, sooth their uneven cashflows, provide improved medical services for their families, and accumulate savings to build assets.  You can  like us on Facebook at: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Liberian-Council-... and follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/licorpa.

Thanking you in anticipation.


If you believe all children should have equal access to quality basic education and the opportunity to learn, then join us to make this happen. Thank You.
