-Share  your posts with friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and Google+ for 9 months, re-tweets your tweets for 6 months, send you  newsletter for 4 quarters, send you LICORPA's full gear(2T-shirts, 2caps, and 2 rubber bracelets), send you beneficiaries progress reports for 8 months, send you  video recording of project activities to watch with your family and say I made this to happen, send you  a carved wood map of Bomi County, and send you  a caricature + novel of Bai T. Moore(Bai T. Moore was great Liberian poet, custodian of  Liberian culture, and a son of Dewoein District)......US$990.00; and,
-Share  your posts with friends on Facebook, followers on Twitter and Google+ for 1 year, re-tweet your tweets for 1 year, send you  newsletter for 1 year, send you  beneficiaries progress for 1 academic year, send you  LICORPA's full gear(4 T-Shirts, 4 caps, and 4 bracelets), send you  video recording of project activities  to watch with your family and say I made it to happen, send you  an African gown, send you  a caricature of students ridding bicycles to school, and send you  a carved wood map of Dewoein District and Bai T. Moore + novel....US$1,155.00. 

Your decision
to donate to our project, will put bicycles in the hands of school children in
Dewoein District. Thank you.


The Impact
 

This project will help to promote regular school attendance and improve learning outcomes
substantially. Moreover, it will help reduce poverty in the province because when the children are educated, they will overcome poverty and consequently  return to contribute to the development of their communities. 

Risks & Challenges
There
are  inherent risks and challenges  in the implementation of the project, and
they are: (1) some students might refuse to go to school after receiving the
bicycles, (2) some students might sell the bicycles and convert the money into
personal use, and (3) some students might decide to use the bicycles
for rental purposes.   To avoid the occurrence of these, the
following outlined measures will be adopted by LICORPA. (1)Community Monitoring Committees (CMC) will
be setup. These committees in collaboration with LICORPA,  will select
 students most in need and oversee the use of the bicycles, (2) Recipients
will learn about bicycle safety and sign an agreement with LICORPA for regular
school attendance, and (3) bi-weekly follow-up visitations will be made by LICORPA's Field Officer to get data on  regular school attendance and learning outcomes of beneficiaries. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
 Perhaps you may have the desire to help financially, but the possibility does not exist. In this regards, you can help us by spreading the word to family members and friends in your network or even setup a fundraising page on your Facebook page and refer our campaign page link. This will highly be appreciated.

Liberian Council on Rural
Poverty Alleviation or LICORPA is a registered not-for-profit
organization with accreditation number 0153 from the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning of the Republic of Liberia. 
LICORPA was established in May 2009 by band of committed Liberians with the
objective of breaking barriers to opportunities for the rural poor, and it
seeks the  vision of self-sufficient and
self-reliant rural poor people who will work for the development of their persons and communities. LICORPA’s pursue a  mission of giving helping hands to
the rural poor to work their way out of poverty and live a dignified and
healthier life. Our program services
include: (i) Education, (ii) Microfinance and (iii) Skills Training. These
program services are designed to help the rural poor to overcome the
dehumanizing effects of poverty. 
Since its inception in May 2009, beneficiaries of LICORPA are now able to send more of their children to school, provide the next meal without untold sufferings, sooth their uneven cashflows, provide improved medical services for their families, and accumulate savings to build assets.  You can  like us on Facebook
at: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Liberian-Council-...
and follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/licorpa.
Thanking you
in anticipation.

If you believe all children should have equal access to quality basic education and the opportunity to learn, then join us to make this happen. Thank You.

story:
I am Ajay Rimal, age of 36, I am founder and Principal of Superb Catalyst Academy, Vice- Chairman of the Prominent Welfare Society, Scouts Master for Nepal Scouts ( SCA Troop) and involved in local clubs with social services. I have a Master's Degree in Political Science from Tribhuvan University. I have been teaching for fifteen years.
My wife Bina Adhilkari Rimal, age of 28,  she is running a Bachelor Degree in Sociology alongside being the administrator at Superb Catalyst Academy and working in local women's groups. We have a seven year old daughter, Eminent Rimal , she prefers her Nepali name "SANSKRITI" which means culture. She reads in Class two at the Academy. Our three month old little daughter passed away  month ago due to cardiovascular arrest.

I founded the academy in 2007 after a final wish from my father, who was a pioneer in bringing English education in  Dhading district of Nepal. Sadly during the political crisis before two decades school failed and he asked me to continue his dream of bringing education to all to develop communities.

Superb Catalyst Academy is a government registered English Medium Secondary School recently relocated in Khanikhola , Dhading a beautiful small valley. Our place is one hour drive from Kathmandu ( 25 Kilometers) , on the way to Pokhara. We currently have 250 students that range from nursery to class 10 (age 4-18).

We want to develop our community by educating young people through active involvement in education, health, agriculture, languages, cultures, lifestyles, music, games and sports, the environment and its sustainability.We spread and share our message globally via our volunteers from all over the world, including UK, Australia,, USA, Switzerland, Denmark, France, Belgium, Sweden,Canada, Italy, Portugal, Spain,New Zealand and many more. We have warmly welcomed more than two hundred volunteers so far. We recently constructed a new school building due to tremendous contributions from our  global community. Thanks to The Parkin Family who donated the entire funds for the Primary school Block. Much Thanks also to Carol Baggarmana and Ron for their endless support and contributions along with our other well-wishers who give endless love and contributions which benefit the lives of 1000s people in the community.

 We have just set up The GMP -  Great Mother's Program, that will help to educate and inform mothers in our comminut, ultimately improving the quality their lives and reflecting a change in the community.

Our aim is to build a simple home with biogas , a rocket stove heater for my small family as well as a dormitory for the  most disadvantaged  children to stay during the school week.

We already have the land which will be big enough to start the schools horticulture program, in which the children will be educated about permaculture and organic methods of farming. Home grown products will provide all of our students with a free healthy lunch and any excess will be sold at the market to  give the school a small  income. Most families can not afford the $5 a month school fees but they are never asked to leave, indeed these are the children we are most concerned with reaching and empowering them in progress in all  aspects of their life.

We now need to reach out again to our extended global community and network to help our project succeed. 

 The landlord has decided to exclude us from the house where we have been living for three years. We finally secured a location in inherited land of Khanikhola, however, the battle has not stopped there. Due to previous help from volunteers and fundraising campaigns, we have been able to complete a new school. Our progress has halted after not having proper place to live Our goal of this fundraiser is to finish the project: ,  We are giving emphasize with bio-gas energy production, that will make life easier for the whole community.

 The Global home will be the place for my family to live and we can directly participate in welcoming volunteers, exchanging cultures, lifestyles, languages and relation build up among the global people in cross-cultural activities. We can increase our efficiency to make the project succeed.

Therefore, we are turning to our larger global community to ask for your help. Help us to complete the home and engage these our mission of social changes on the path of multidimensional approaches . We know the love and support are not only there, but are continuing to grow. Above all, please share the message and evidence of the good works at SCA. Awareness can be the largest contributing factor to positive change, and we hope our network continues to only expand.

Peace, love and appreciation in taking the time to read this. If you are interested in helping in any way, shape or form, please refer to the references below. Inclusive nature does not limit itself to only the school , and  vision of the SCA community expands much further than the school grounds in Khanikhola.

Superb Catalyst Academy’s Website

http://superbcatalystacademy.co.nr

Superb Catalyst Academy’s Facebook Page

https://www.facebook.com/SuperbCatalystAcademy

Previous SCA Videos

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yds3GY2nPRY

We are waiting  to bring you latest Videos:

Network of Superb Catalyst Academy

Superb Catalyst Volunteer and Support Team:

https://www.facebook.com/groups/825608090783065/

Give with Soul:

https://www.facebook.com/givewithSOUL/info

Travelling with a Purpose (SCA’s International Project Director, Carol Baggarman):

https://www.facebook.com/GivingItBackTravelingBeautiful

What is Biogas? (a BBC World article):

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15991384

We are keeping our fingers crossed.

story:
OUR STORY

It is time to make a difference... IN GERMANY! 

We have been working for the past four years on the Bonobo-Human Discourse (BHD) research project led by Emeritus professors James Benson and the late William Greaves. We study inter-species communication, specifically communication between human caregivers/researchers and bonobos, currently located at the Ape Cognition and Conservation Initiative (ACCI) in Des Moines, Iowa. You can check out their page here.  

The three of us were fortunate to have the opportunity to intern at ACCI for the past three summers. To see what an amazing experience this was, please click here.

For the past couple of years, our team has presented the research internationally and at home. This year, we focused on a major study providing evidence for the bonobos' ability to answer questions like: who, what, where, when, why. 

Our research report has been accepted at the 42nd International Systemic Functional Congress in Aachen, Germany in July 2015. 


WHERE FUNDS GO

We believe that our attendance at this conference will allow us not only to share our research but also to spread awareness about the  bonobos' underestimated and under appreciated ability to communicate with humans.  

Anything that is donated will help us cover travel and accommodation expenses to Germany. 

We appreciate any amount of support and thank you for your generosity. 

Sincerely,

The BHD Team

story:
Give the gift of education, and take part in a live exploration of the power of the 'Gift Economy'.

Will you help me to fund my studies and complete an MA in Ecological Design Thinking at Schumacher College, which will allow me to reach my potential and play my part in co-creating a more harmonious world where life flourishes...?

After a lot searching, I have finally found it!

A place of education with a focus on holistic learning, where it's not just "business as usual". Schumacher College puts community back at the heart of education, and transforms people into transformers...not big gun-toting robots...positive changemakers that transform the world around them! A lot of truly inspiring people have graduated before me, and it is an honour to follow in their footsteps.

Schumacher College is a microcosm where the mysteries of the macrocosm are explored, and great things happen! A place that is at the forefront of shifting us into a new paradigm of learning, teaching, doing and creating.

My Journey

My journey here has been a windy path...
I have a BSc in neuroscience, an MA in Digital Media and a Postgraduate Diploma in Consciousness Studies & Transpersonal Psychology. I have a Permaculture Design qualification; I bake bread and make fermented and living foods; I am an EFT practitioner; I have a Gong - which I use for meditation & relaxation sessions; as a result of my ongoing interest in wellbeing, I have started an organisation called Well, Well, Well; I have walked across Spain; I have worked in many places, from factories to offices to a farm; I love to be of service to people; I feel that prevention is better than cure; I don't like to make judgements of people or situations; I feel that life is a mystery to be lived, not a problem to be solved.   

I am grateful for all of my life experiences and I have been weaving a thread through these diverse elements of my life. Pulling on that thread has brought me here to the Ecological Design Thinking Masters course. Being here is providing me with an opportunity to consolidate all that I have done so far, and raise the level of my contribution to the world.

Ecological Design Thinking

I have joined a band of ecologically minded pilgrims, and together we are exploring how we can design and co-create a world where life flourishes. All life. When I look at the world, with its seeming bleakness I see opportunity. Opportunity to change, opportunity to act out of love rather than fear. An opportunity to make things 'more good' rather than just 'less bad'.

A wise man once told me, "Focus on the solution, not the problem"...a mantra that has stayed with and inspired me ever since. And one that we are adopting on the course. We know what the problems are already. There are also a lot of great people doing amazing things - we need to bring the pieces of this jigsaw together and complete the picture...of a world that is even more wonderful.

Reality is way more magical and mystical than we have been led to believe - We are an interconnected, interdependent part of a much larger whole. When we start acting like it, that's when the magic happens...

We need to learn to trust Nature a bit more. Nature has been around for a while, we can trust her. Our mistrust of Nature, leads to a mistrust of ourselves and a mistrust of each other. And without trust, things are a lot more difficult.

These are some of the ideas that I am bringing into my work - with a particular focus on wellbeing, looking at how the wellbeing of people and the wellbeing of the planet relate to each other..to me they are inseparable. 

Different Ways of Being

Why fund someone else's education you may be asking? Because we are all interconnected in ways that we are only just beginning to fully comprehend. Being able to ask, to give and to receive is what lies at the heart of community, building trust and strengthening relationships, authentic relationships that serve the community, from local communities to global communities. Sharing knowledge, skills and possessions, and enabling and empowering others is the most rewarding thing that we can do.

There are 3 concepts at the heart of this campaign:

1) The Gift Economy (e.g. The Gift Economy): Giving for the sake of giving, without the expectation of something in return. We are born into a Gift Economy, practiced by those who mother and raise us, enabling us to survive. The economy of exchange which then appears in our lives further down the line, separates us from each other and makes us adversarial, while gift giving and receiving creates mutuality and trust.

2) Random Acts of Kindness. Going out of your way to help another purely for the sake of helping them. Helping because you can. Particularly when they least expect it. It's a concept that I hold dear to my heart. I encourage you to do the same, even if you are unable to contribute to this campaign.

3) 'Pay It Forward'. Rather than having someone 'pay you back' (the exchange economy in action, on subtle levels) encourage them to 'pay it forward' instead. Helping others in a time of need (with a 'random act of kindness' perhaps) based on the memory of being helped out before when help was needed (especially powerful when it's someone unknown to you/them). Passing on the good vibrations and increasing the harmony in the world.

As a thank you for helping me to fulfil this dream of studying at Schumacher College, I will be 'paying it forward' by offering some of my skills and assistance to others in the future (at little or no cost. e.g. Gong meditations and EFT therapy to those in need).

Story

Everything in our lives is story - stories play an important role. The stories we tell ourselves and tell each other, the stories our family and peers tell us, the stories the media, politicians and advertising tell us, they all have wide reaching and powerful effects. The seemingly destructive and disconnected world we find ourselves living in, is just a story...and we have an opportunity to tell a new story, based on the values that serve everyone and everything, and reflect the magic of reality.

The work that I am doing here on the Ecological Design Thinking course, is contributing to a new story, with a focus on wellbeing and healing, moving away from fear based actions, and trusting nature. You can be part of my story, and join me on this journey, by contributing toward my campaign.

Join me

I've put everything I have into being here on this course, and have come up a little short financially. This feels like a very important chapter in my life, and one that will have far reaching effects. We live in uncertain times, and I am allowing my journey to unfold in front of me, with faith that it will lead to where I need to be. I am responding to a call to step up and take responsibility for the part I play in the world.

My heart and my gut are telling me this is where I need to be now to play offer my gifts to the world and participate in the unfolding of something wonderful for us all...to play my part in realising the collective dream. 

Having you supporting me on this journey, empowering me, so that I may in turn empower others, is a real honour. Thank you for being involved! Whatever gift you are able to offer is truly appreciated - all of our actions produce ripples, and your positivity will have far reaching effects.

I am truly grateful for this opportunity, and I have already learned so much.

So thank you, be well, go in peace, and may you be blessed by the light of a thousand suns...

With Love

Faze x

story:
*Special thanks to Heather Martin for interpreting our video. Heather will graduate this summer from the Ohio University Lancaster Interpreter Training Program.

 


My name is Chris Harris, and I, along with my fellow students, want to share Aikido and fellowship with my community. We have all chipped in to make this happen, and we will continue to fund ourselves as much as possible. Given the scope of what we are trying to acheive, we are reaching out for your help.

Our mission is to provide a safe, harmonious environment where people, regardless of age, race, gender, body type, or religion can practice and study the art of Aikido. AikiState is committed to expanding our knowledge of Aikido by traditional, modern, and innovative training methods.

We are devoted to serving the community though humanitarian activities as well, and we intend to share our love for our community through several community service activities throughout our year.

We also wish to include the Deaf community in our practice. Tampa Bay harbors more than 4 million people, and a large Deaf community as well. I hope to be able to share my art with this often overlooked, but wholly engaged group. Both my wife and I have a bit of training in ASL, American Sign Language, and we have always enjoyed both the culture and the people of the Deaf community. We hope to include this group in our dojo in a way that has not been done before. We would like to invite the Deaf community of Tampa Bay into our lives, our hearts, our dojo.


What We Need & What You Get

**For corporate sponsorship opportunities, please contact us via AikiState@Gmail.com

**Tee Shirt designs can be viewed in the gallery**

For our dojo to be able to support the capacity we are anticipating, we will be using funds raised for the following:

·  Practice Space $15000

·  Mats $7000

·  Marketing $3000

·  Décor and Seating $2000

·  Training Equipment $1000

·  Business Fees and other related expenses $2000

BREAK DOWN AND PERKS

  • Practice space- We are currently looking at several options for dojo space. Once the campaign is completed and we have a better idea of our budget, we will make the final decision. 


  • We are estimating practice space funds at $15000. This will cover six months of rent  ($9000), six months of utilities ($3000),  six months of insurance ($500), paint and cleaning supplies for initial move-in ($1500), and new signs for our new dojo ($1000).

  • Mats for our dojo- ($7000)   We are excited to be adding brand new mats on which our members can safely practice. We will be ordering Dollamur mats directly from the manufacturer, at a cost of $4683.26, for a square footage of 860. The remaining mat funds will be used to create a raised platform on which the mats will sit, allowing for better spring and more comfortable falls. We are estimating the cost of building this platform at around $2300.


  • Marketing- In order to announce our official arrival to Tampa Bay, we will be spending an initial investment of $2000 into local newspaper, television, and billboard ads. This will also include fliers and stickers given at all our local colleges and universities, we expect this initial investment to cover approximately the first two months of marketing materials. The remaining funds will be put towards welcome packages for new members.

  •  Decor and Seating-  In order to align ourselves with Aikido tradition, we will be placing a kamiza in the front of the mats. This Japanese tradition honors our founder by placing a picture of him alongside a few weapons and decorations. We consider this to be the crown of our dojo, and will be spending no less that $750 on this single piece. The remaining $1250 will be spent on visitor seating, benches in locker rooms, and overall decor.

  • Training equipment-  We would like our students to be prepared in any situation, and therefore we will also provide weapons training. Our budget for these supplies are as follows: Tonto (wooden knives, pictured below)- set of 15- $150. Bokken ( wooden sword, pictured below)- set of 15 $240. Jo (wooden staff, pictured below) Set of 15- $300. Weapons rack (pictured below) set of two- $90. Training hand guns - 2 for $30. Decorative basket for small weapons - $30.

  • . Remaining budget will be used for weapons maintenance and a library of used Aikido books.



  • Business fees and other related expenses. As with any profitable business, we are aware and prepared for the necessary buget for administrative costs. This includes; an LLC filing at an approximate cost of $300, Legal representation and advice at a cost of approximately $400, business licenses $100, $1000 for CPA services, and the remaining $200 will be spent on Anime and hoola hoops. (Just making sure you are still paying attention!)


                        PERKS and stretch goals!!

We are very excited about our perks.



  • Our dojo will strive to expose our members to cultural differences and create a better world by producing students who are confident and able to adapt to new situations. As a group we will have a continued commitment to better our community, and ourselves, through humanitarian activities and community involvement.

Risks & Challenges

As with most martial arts schools, our first and biggest challenege will be to maintain a student base that will allow us to cover overhead expenses. At a rate of approx. $50 per month, that is just over 40 students. We currently have a base of ten students. in order to gain the other 30 or so, we intend to market to not only the Deaf community but also to the colleges and universities in our area, including St. Petersburg College, University of South Florida, Eckerd College, and Stetson University, all of which have campuses within 10 miles of our current location.
Our second challenge will be bridging the communication gap between hearing and Deaf students. We intend to solve this by inviting any available interpreter to come to class absolutely free of charge. We also will be constantly encouraging hearing students to learn the beautiful art of American Sign Language. We believe this will add to their lives not only a new form of communication, but a respect for other cultures. Just as our students learn technique names in Japanese, we be encouraging everyone to learn the signs needed for Aikido practice as well.

We expect that many of the Japanese technique names will not have an ASL equivalent, so we look forward to working with our Deaf members and interpreters to create signs as needed.


Other Ways You Can Help

We are beyond thankful to our funders, but we also know how important people can be even if they don't add to our goal directly. 

We ask that whether you plan to contribute or not, you please take a moment to share our campaign. We want this idea to be spread as far and wide as possible. 

Indiegogo makes this easy by giving you "share" buttons for social media, please use them as often as possible.  

Do you know someone who might be interested in our project? Let them know! Send a quick personal note along with your share!


THANK YOU!

**A special note from Chris Harris**

     I want to thank everyone for making this dream come true for myself and my practice parntners.  My pledge to you all is that I will work day and night to overcome any obstacles, so that your funding and our hard work will bear the fruit of positivity and unity. I strongly believe in the idea of spreading peace and harmony throughout my community, and you have my deepest gratitude for making this a reality.

Sincerely,

Chris Harris

story:
During the November 2015-February 2016 period, Daryl and Katie are teaming up with Volunteer Eco Students Abroad and the Laos Elephant Conservation Centre to provide essential infrastructure, veterinary and medical care, and education to local communities in South East Asia. 

Volunteer Eco Students Abroad is an organization working hand in hand with indigenous village communities to create real and lasting change.

The Elephant Conservation Centre is a non-profit organisation which has been working towards the protection of elephants in Laos for over 12 years, running welfare, vet care, breeding and mahouts training programmes. The Centre, together with VESA, is dedicated to protecting ancestral cultures, knowledge and traditions, as well as the fragile tropical ecosystem. With only two elephants born for every ten that die, the Asian elephant, a major component of Lao cultural heritage, is under serious threat of extinction.

During our time in Laos we will be under the guidance of local Indigenous communities: planting banana and sugar cane crops; maintaining the veterinary clinic and elephant nursery; building classrooms, bathroom blocks and water catchments; and working within local schools to provide an introduction to English and assist kids in breaking the poverty cycle. As people from Australia, we will be adhering to cultural practices and traditions, and be working closely with members of the community to ensure that our actions represent what is best for the region.

Your donation will go towards our transport, accommodation and meals, as well as all building materials and the hiring of local tradespeople. Should we exceed our target, anything leftover will go as a monetary donation to the Elephant Conservation Centre to ensure that their work can continue. 

Please share, and help us reach our goal!

story:
Hello there! : My name is Christy and thanks so much for reading this!  I work in schools in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.  My job involves supporting the best kids in the world! OK, well, that's my opinion.  I move from school to school (staying 3-6 weeks at a time in one school), and do short-term, intensive behaviour support.  This amazing job allows me to love on a lot of kids and teachers, but also it allows me to see needs that others may not. 


Why care?!: The classroom that I am working in until the 23rd of April, is in an Inner City School.  Inner city schools have breakfast programs, hot lunch programs, and some children are even sent home with food on weekends, or else they won't get enough to eat.  The basics of life stand out in this school, because it's the things we take for granted that are most needed.  


My idea!: In my class, 75-80% of the kids have a hard time concentrating, simply because they are unable to sit still long enough to hear what is being said!  Today I was observing from the back of the classroom and thought about "chair cushions" and how helpful they would be for these  kids.  The real name for them are "Exersit Seat Cushions".  They are a flat, plastic, air filled cushion, that kids put on their chairs, and then sit on them during class.  This allows a little bit of wiggle room (literally), while remaining seated.  


As SILLY as it may sound, these would make a WORLD of difference for these kids, and there is NO funding available for these sorts of tools, especially when an entire class needs them.    

Let's do this!: I called Odin Books, which is the store that the schools here in Vancouver use for most of their materials, and I asked what they recommended. I was informed that they do ample research and only purchase the best products, and they are willing to order a bunch of these cushions for us, as well have a few in stock.


[Odin Books: http://odinbooks.com ]
[ http://www.relaxusonline.com/Exer_Sit_Balancing... ]

Each cushions costs $27.95.  Odin will give us a 10% discount for a large order.  So, my goal would to be able to purchase 30 of them. That way I can gift one for each member of my class, and give a couple to the resource centre at this school.  

My goal is 30, but I cannot do it alone, so if you're interested in helping, it would be so much fun to bless this class with this gift, before I leave their school on the 23rd. 

*Disclaimer: The Vancouver School Board is not aware I am funding this, so they        take zero responsibility for this.  It's just me, separate from them.  As well, for privacy, I have left out the name of the school.*

story:
Hi I'm Amie Newberry, from McQueen High School.  I teach.  Actually, more accurately, I love to teach!  While technically, I teach English, my true goal is to help students realize and utilize their unique gifts and talents to serve others in their community and the world.

Every year, we host the “Museum of Me” event and showcase a portfolio of work from every student; each student has over 45 pieces of writing on display for family and friends to read and enjoy.  It is a beautiful and stunning event.  Last year we had almost 600 people in attendance. 

This year, in addition to the Museum of Me, we’ve decided to incorporate a “Grand Exhibition” and every student will frame and display his/her best work (in an up-cycled cereal box) which family and friends can purchase. 

We are attempting to raise $5,000--a bold, but doable goal--for Touch a Life Foundation, which helps free children from slavery in Ghana, West Africa and rehabilitate them so they can have productive lives. 

Five thousand dollars will go a long way in Ghana; to put it in perspective, many desperate parents of enslaved children in Ghana sell their child for as little as $20 dollars. 

We believe every child deserves to be free, every child deserves a childhood! 

In my years of teaching, I've done two large fundraising projects which have generated over $15,000 each.  I feel gifted in helping students find their talents and helping them use those talents to help make an impact on world issues.

No matter what we raise--it will make a difference.  So if you have a heart for service, or service has changed your heart, please partner with us!  Please help me show these students that it's important and meaningful to tackle problems that exist, that it's powerful to do good in the world, and that being passionate and bold in our culture can cure global injustice.

Thank you and please pass this link on!

Amie Newberry

story:
Who we are:

For 54 years, the Boys & Girls Clubs of Weld County, has been serving youth ages 6 to 18 years old in after school and summer programming. Our mission is to inspire and enable all youth, especially those who need us most, to become productive, responsible and caring citizens. We accomplish this for a membership fee only $10 per school year and $10 per summer for each child or teen. Our areas in which we provide activities in are: Academic Success, Good Character & Citizenship, Healthy Lifestyles, and The Arts. On average we see over 525 kids per day during the school year. During the summer this number will be nearly 700 youth members in total at 8 our facilities! We expect 60 of these youth to be active members of our Teen Center located in Greeley, Colorado.

 

The teens we serve:

Teen programming is geared towards academic success and community engagement. We have several local partnerships to support college and career preparation. Our teens are also highly engaged within the community, and have been nominated for 5 awards at the national level from the Boy & Girls Clubs of America!

Sending them on this college trip encourages them to realize their dreams. When you invest in our youth, you are showing them that all of their hard work will pay off and that you personally believe in them.

You would be surprised how powerful a small investment of encouragement can alter the path of a single youth. We appreciate your support!

 

What's the plan?

We are looking to take 8 Teen Club Members on a week-long trip to expand their awareness of education and culture. With a goal of raising $8,000 we have plans for the following:

  • Airfare and lodging in a select region of the US – Current options include:
    • Northeast United States / Northern California-Utah-Nevada / Hawaii

 

  • Campus Visits to at least 5 Universities

 

  • Educational Tours and Site Seeing         

For the duration of this campaign, our teens will be putting together the plan for their trip including planning for costs, transportation, sightseeing locations, and overall logistics! 

Stay tuned for more details!

 

Why:

Think about your life and all of the things that you've accomplished or places you've been... Or maybe think about what you wish you were able to do or places you wanted to go...

Now put yourself in the shoes of a group of local teens that have barely begun to see the world outside of Northern Colorado, a group of teens who have faced substantial struggle in their lives. Your support will give our youth the courage, confidence and motivation to creatively explore their dreams.

Remember, these teens are our future and will soon become the young adult leaders in our community. It is crucial that we invest in them now because they are the ones that are going to shape the world for many years to come.

Over the last 5 years a new cohort of teens have traveled the nation expanded their horizons. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity and it is something that brings hope to their lives. This year they are pushing past previous expectations and are reaching for the stars, please help them accomplish their lofty goals. 

 

Risks & Challenges:

The biggest hurdle for this trip is safety. Depending on the size of the group, we will need to have several staff on the clock at all times. 

  • No stranger to field trips, even overnight ones, we have policies and procedures in place to ensure their safety and well-being. As the trip is finalized, staff will be scheduled to lead this trip for proper supervision and adequate time off the clock.

Other Ways You Can Help:

We ask that you to give what you can and know that every gift, no matter how small will help to open a new world of educational opportunities to vulnerable youth in our community. Even if you are unable to contribute financially, please share with your network for someone who might be able to! 

We appreciate your help and support, thank you for taking the time to read one of the many great opportunities that youth receive when they come to Boys & Girls Clubs of Weld County.

Over the last 5 years a new cohort of teens have traveled the nation expanded their horizons. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity and it is something that brings hope to their lives. This year they are pushing past previous expectations and are reaching for the stars, please help them accomplish their lofty goals. 
 
Risks & Challenges:
The biggest hurdle for this trip is safety. Depending on the size of the group, we will need to have several staff on the clock at all times. 
No stranger to field trips, even overnight ones, we have policies and procedures in place to ensure their safety and well-being. As the trip is finalized, staff will be scheduled to lead this trip for proper supervision and adequate time off the clock.

Other Ways You Can Help:
We ask that you to give what you can and know that every gift, no matter how small will help to open a new world of educational opportunities to vulnerable youth in our community. Even if you are unable to contribute financially, please share with your network for someone who might be able to! 
We appreciate your help and support, thank you for taking the time to read one of the many great opportunities that youth receive when they come to Boys & Girls Clubs of Weld County.

story:
The Summer Sizzzle BVI group are joining efforts to support the rebuilding of the largest public high school in the British Virgin Islands. In September of 2017, Hurricane Irma brought devastation to the BVI, destroying or severely damaging nearly all buildings. Amongst the havoc left by Irma was the destruction of the Elmore Stoutt High School, rendering most of the building unusable just as the island’s students were about to embark on their new school year.

The Summer Sizzle BVI community, would like to raise enough money to assist families to provide school supplies to students to help in the restoration of Elmore Stoutt High School so that students can return to their normal day-to-day routines and the teachers can continue providing the students with the education they deserve.

Our goal is to provide new backpacks with school supplies to 1100 Elmore Stoutt High school students in the British Virgin Islands.

We have secured good quality backpacks filled with supplies at a low cost of only $9.50 per student!

OUR GOAL IS TO RAISE $12,000

100% of all funds raised will go toward the ELMORE STOUTT SCHOOL SUPPLIES RESTORATION DRIVE and TOWARD TRANSPORTATION OF THE ITEMS

Your generous donation will help young individuals get the school year started and on the right foot.

After the hurricane, all was lost in certain cases and the school system is desperately doing all it can to facilitate the continuation of their yearly curriculum and with your help we can get this mission accomplished.

Backpacks and supplies will be distributed by the school board....the ultimate goal is to provide every Elmore Stoutt student a backpack with proper school supplies on the island of TORTOLA.

It’s vital to keep a positive outlook and attitude on the islands and overcome great tragedy.

 

The Challenge We Are Facing

Many families are struggling. With high unemployment as a result of the devastation on the island, and more than 1100 students enrolled many parents are unable to provide the basic school supplies their children need to be effective. As a result of the ongoing rebuilding and  restoration initiatives the school system lacks the funding to purchase necessary supplies.

We are helping to ensure that students start the school year with the tools they need to succeed.

We are Helping teachers by providing them with proper tools for their classrooms so they don’t have to spend money from their own pockets.

By providing these school supplies, you are supporting students, teachers and the School

 

About US

Summer Sizzle Is a FASHION/Style runway show with local excursions and themed parties that celebrates the paradise and cultures of the BVI.

Celebrities, Designers, Models and press along with tourism from all over the world have enjoyed the island through the SUMMER SIZZLE experience and we want to continue that tradition.

This year's initiative is to REBUILD, RESTORE, REVIVE the paradise we all have grown to love and adore.

story:
Short Summary test

BAMI - March Chagall community school is a medium size primary school and kindergarden with around 300 children. BAMI - March Chagall community school also has its own sports center and a vibrant set of extracurricular activities for adults and children (chess, clowns, sports, etc), being the unique Jewish life center in the area.

But BAMI - March Chagall community school has gone through serious difficult times. Because of the argentinean economic crisis, many families have left the neighborhood and the institution survived many threats of closing, raising money to continue with its activities from its contributors. But the same little number of donors cannot afford the cost of mantaining alive the school. That's why we need your help!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The school has a deficit of 45.000 A$ (argentinean Pesos), about U$ 3.000 per month. It is U$ 36.000 per year.
  • We can reach about U$ 10.000 in argentinean donors, but we still need U$ 26.000 more to sustain alive the entire school all year long.
  • With this grant we can guarantee education for 300 children and their families for the entire year.

 

The Impact

  • One of the most threatening problems is the lack of education for life. An open education which could teach not only technical skills but humanitarian skills as well. An education which could teach how to interact with other religions in search of peace an harmony.
  • With this grant, we will have 300 future new leaders, who will be able to change actual and future problems.

story:
Bonjour!

My name is Geri Metz. I live in Mount Shasta, California, a small town at the foot of the 14,000 mountain. I am a former French teacher, now 80 years old, and I am the creator of this project. I have a Master’s degree in French from Middlebury College Language School in Middlebury, Vermont.  I taught French at both the high school and university levels, and my specialty was phonetics or the sounds of a language. To check my website for more details about my life and career CLICK HERE.

What is the Project?

Mastering French Pronunciation: Video Course is to be a 7-chapter course taught by me on video.  I have already written the course material, and the next step is to do the filming.  

The course material teaches the basics of good pronunciation, taking up each vowel and consonant sound in detail, but it goes much further than that.  My special contribution is that I pose the question, “Are you speaking French with an American mouth?”   A student can imitate the sounds of a language with fair accuracy, but if he or she is forming those sounds with the mouth posture of the English language, the result will never be authentic-sounding French.  So the main emphasis of this teaching is helping students overcome the speech habits of their native language.

Another essential part of the teaching is providing practice exercises so the student can repeat the sounds presented in each lesson.  Rather than provide an audio recording for practice, we will be featuring a native speaker of French on the videos, so students can not only hear the sounds, but see the mouth positions of the speaker for an even better chance to imitate accurately.

Some language students have avoided phonetics in their studies, thinking the subject is too technical or too difficult.  With this in mind, I have made this course very easy to understand and non-technical.  For French people in particular, the way a foreigner pronounces their language is very important; they don’t care so much if you use a wrong word; if you say the word properly, all is forgiven!  I feel that this course is unique in the field and fills a need that no other program touches on. 

It is planned that the seven chapter video course will sell for $59.95 on dvd.

Current Status:

I send out a written report to all who join my mailing list on the website. This is a comprehensive article that answers the question, “Are you speaking French with an American mouth?” You can find it HERE. 

To publicize my work, for the past four months I have been posting weekly a free mini video lesson in French pronunciation called Word of the Week.  This little lesson goes out to those who enroll through the website or who subscribe through YouTube.  Please go to the links below to see three examples of these mini lessons which will give you an idea of my teaching method.  I have given below a little summary of the content of each of the three. You can see all of the Word of the Week videos by going to my YouTube channel.  While you are there, please click the “thumbs up” button below the video or leave a comment.  This brings me up in the ratings.


Word of the Week subject:  the French “r”.  Many people think this uniquely French sound is hard to make and sounds harsh, but in reality it is very soft and quite easy to learn.


Word of the Week subject:  “euh”.  This lesson contrasts the different basic mouth positions of English and French.  These mouth postures produce the sound we use to pause—and the lesson shows how to make the correct sound in French.


Word of the Week subject: rhythm.  An interesting lesson for Americans, showing the rhythm of our language and how it is very different from French.


Who is the target audience for the course?

I designed the course originally to reach French teachers who are my former colleagues and whom I admire greatly for the contribution they make to promoting the French language and culture in their classes. I am hoping that many of them will take advantage of this course to perfect their accent so they can be a more accurate model for the next generation.

But in addition to teachers, I feel that this course will be very useful to students, especially those majoring in French or those going overseas for Junior Year Abroad or other exchange programs.  Another group of young people who would profit from the course are those going to French speaking countries as an au pair or live-in nanny.

Business people who work for international companies with branches in France or other French speaking countries or who actually work overseas.  

Other potential customers include Foreign Service personnel, 

Actors and singers and especially the many travelers who go to France each year. 

My mission is to help these people realize their goal of sounding more authentic when speaking French.

Funding Needs:

I have already spent over $6000 to get this project started.  These expenses include:  

  • Graphic and Web Design
  • SEO Search Engine Optimization
  • Purchase of a new computer
  • Video and editing expenses of producing the Word of the Week
  • Advertising design and publication of an ad in four issues of The French Review (Official scholarly review of the American Association of Teachers of French)
  •  Purchasing booth space at the annual convention of that organization
  • A direct mail campaign
  • And various printing expenses

I will definitely need financial help to complete the project.  The requested funding will pay for the production and editing of the videos of the course material, printing of the dvds and further marketing outreach.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out!   Whether you can contribute monetarily or not, please  share this campaign on all your social media outlets. Tell your friends, family, and anyone you know of who might be interested in Mastering French Pronunciation or in supporting me in this effort. Small amounts from lots of people can make this project a huge success! Let's make it to the goal so that the Mastering French course can be as great as it can be and so people around the world will hear about it!  Thank you for your generous support!

story:
AN INTERNATIONAL DIALOG ABOUT DEATH AND BEYOND


WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE DO 

With more hard scientific evidence about life after death emerging each year, it’s becoming increasingly difficult to deny that consciousness survives after death. That’s the focus of the upcoming Fifth Annual Afterlife Awareness Conference, where scientists, physicians, spiritual teachers and grief counselors will gather to share their knowledge about end-of-life care, near-death experience, after-death communication, conscious dying and conscious grieving.

The conference will be held in Norfolk, Va. June 4-7, 2015,  and will feature renowned  experts such as Eben Alexander, M.D.,  recognized worldwide for his best-selling book, Proof of Heaven, and Raymond Moody, M.D., Ph.D, author of the breakthrough book Life After Life, and  known for coining the term "near-death experience." Also on the roster are Anita Moorjani, author of the New York Times best-seller, Dying to be Me, psychic medium John Holland and many other noted leaders in the field.

“Although death is not a popular topic for cocktail party chatter, making plans for the end of life is one of the greatest gifts we can give to ourselves and our loved ones," explains conference founder Terri Daniel.  "Our program covers everything from scientific research on near-death experience to spiritual and sociological practices for assisting the dying. It's a rare opportunity to find medical doctors and mystics working side-by-side. We like to say that it's an event where shamans break bread with scientists."

The Afterlife Conference is organized into four separate interest tracks that explore death and the afterlife through a variety of different lenses that include:

. Spiritual Exploration
. Academic Research
. Bereavement
. Higher Consciousness in Clinical Settings

Dr. Raymond Moody, the world's leading pioneer in near-death research, is on the advisory board of the Afterlife Conference, and says, “It is inspiring to see how these different perspectives lead to the same place--an awareness of the survival of consciousness after death. The bereaved find peace and healing. The spiritual seekers find validation for their mystical experiences. The physicians find metaphysical tools for their clinical practices. And the scientific researchers find an eager audience for their work.”

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE USED

To promote our 2015 conference in Norfolk, Virginia, the  $12,000 will be used to purchase a radio sponsorship package on an NPR station in Washington DC (WAMU). The campaign will cost $12,000, and will include 40 promotional spots and 36 ticket giveaway announcements over a three-week period.  As we enter our fifth year, we hope to attract a more mainstream audience that includes medical professionals, academics and political decision makers.

story:
Update:

(2/6/15) Thanks to a grant from the New Jersey Historical Commission, we have about 60% of the funds needed to install this new exhibit!  Help us with the remaining funds needed to preserve Alice Paul's story with an exhibit at her home.

Be a part of the legacy...

The Alice Paul Institute (API) is a non-profit organization dedicated to educating the public about the life and work of New Jersey suffragist, Alice Stokes Paul (1885-1977), author of the Equal Rights Amendment, founder of the National
Woman’s Party, and a lifelong activist for women’s equality. Paulsdale, Alice Paul’s birthplace and family home in Mount Laurel is a National Historic Landmark and site on the New Jersey Women’s Heritage Trail and is a center for celebrating and
studying women’s history and leadership.

About the exhibit

Alice Paul: In Pursuit of Ordinary Equality is the first permanent exhibit at Paulsdale. It honors the legacy of suffragist and equal rights activist Alice Stokes Paul (1885-1977) and features family photographs, personal objects, and other memorabilia. Wall panels throughout the first floor of the house detail each chapter of Alice Paul’s lifelong work for equality. Guests will now be able to enjoy a self-guided visitor experience at their own pace anytime Paulsdale is open, in addition to guided tours by appointment. The exhibit honors the principles of peace, human rights, social justice and equality that guided Paul in her work. With the Alice Paul: In Pursuit of Ordinary Equality  exhibit, visitors will find the same inspiration for peace and change that Paul once found at her childhood home.

View sample panels from the exhibit by clicking the gallery tab above.


What we need

Your financial support will help to bring Alice Paul’s legacy to life at historic Paulsdale. The exhibit is designed, and with your help we can complete the last
phase to fabricate and install it. Any level of support for the exhibit is welcome. In addition to perks at each giving level, all supporters will be recognized in API publications and will receive a personal invitation to the ribbon-cutting ceremony at the opening of the Alice Paul: In Pursuit of Ordinary Equality exhibit.


To learn more about the Alice Paul: In Pursuit of Ordinary Equality  exhibit, contact Kris Myers, API Program Director at 856-231-1885 or email kmyers@alicepaul.org. For more information about the Alice Paul Institute visit www.alicepaul.org.

story:
Who are we?

We are Casco Bay’s class of 2016. In short, we are 91 independent, driven, hopeful high school juniors, seeking an opportunity to learn beyond the classroom. We are also budding artists, activists, and volunteers. We are carrying on the tradition of Expeditionary Learning where you gain the most by going out into the real world, fearlessly, knowing that you have a safety net in the beautiful, unique individuals surrounding you. We are jokesters, to tell the truth, but when it comes to identifying and solving the problems of today’s world, I don’t believe there is group of teenagers more passionate, courageous, and inventive than the class of 2016. We are your neighbors, relatives, customers, future employees, and maybe complete strangers, but we are friends. We are the supportive voices of the future, and we need your help.

What is Junior Journey?

The mission of the Junior Journey is to involve CBHS juniors in a one-week, cross-cultural learning experience that will expand students’ sense of both their world and who they are through service and adventure learning. Previous CBHS students and staff have travelled to Biloxi, Mississippi and Almost Heaven, West Virginia to document the journeys of residents whose lives have been impacted by the BP Oil Spill and Hurricane Katrina, as well as participating in service projects with Habitat for Humanity to help rebuild their communities. This year, over the week of April 12-18, the class of 2016 is going to Rockaway, New York, a community that was devastated by Hurricane Sandy and is still in the process of rebuilding itself. In addition to this service project, juniors will learn how to tell powerful stories through documentary in a process that includes interviewing area residents from our Expeditionary Learning partner school in Red Hook, New York and compiling oral histories to draw on and learn from the life experiences of others.

Former Junior Journey participants say:

“Although I am only 18, Junior Journey is, and I believe will always be, one of the most influential and life changing moments of my life.”

“Seeing the inside of her [the interviewee’s] home was very humbling to me, but knowing that the rain won't leak through her ceiling because of the roof that I helped build for her is very inspiring.”

“I always took my class for granted before, but now I realize just how amazing and unique each and every individual who was on the experience with me truly is.”

Why do we need money?

Buses, shelter, food... There are many things that go into getting 91 students from Portland, Maine to Rockaway, New York, and back. And our teachers have not been shy about telling us the rule: no funds, no trip. Such is the way of the world.

Any donation, small or large, gets us one step closer to our goal of $2,500 raised through online funding. The entire trip will cost about $50,000, a generous amount of which has already been covered by a combination of grants, local fundraisers, and parent contributions. However, we still have a ways to go, and are nowhere near where we need to be. As I mentioned, any amount is graciously appreciated, and if you would like we have a couple of perks available, including a complete DVD disc drive of our documentaries once they are finished, a limited edition class of 2016 Junior Journey t-shirt, and a thank you shoutout at one of our infamous school meetings. Feel free to contact us with any questions about money and donations.

Why should you care?

Because you know us. Well, you most likely don’t know all of us, but we are high school students, and you probably know some of those. You know how hard it is for high schoolers to learn in traditional settings, both socially and academically. And Casco Bay High School’s Junior Journey is an amazing opportunity for students to put themselves out there and learn from the real world and real people, fostering real friendships along the way. You know what it’s like to feel excited and inspired about the future of the world, and you care about exciting and inspiring youth, and giving the next generation an educational experience that will help shape them into motivated, intelligent leaders of tomorrow.

How can you help?

Besides donating the obvious way, we could use your help to spread the word about our campaign. Please share us on Facebook or Twitter or whatever you use, and tell a few friends to check us out. On behalf of the class of 2016, I thank you so much for your generosity and support.
story_txt: Who are we?We are Casco Bay’s class of 2016. In short, we are 91 independent, driven, hopeful high school juniors, seeking an opportunity to learn beyond the classroom. We are also budding artists, activists, and volunteers. We are carrying on the tradition of Expeditionary Learning where you gain the most by going out into the real world, fearlessly, knowing that you have a safety net in the beautiful, unique individuals surrounding you. We are jokesters, to tell the truth, but when it comes to identifying and solving the problems of today’s world, I don’t believe there is group of teenagers more passionate, courageous, and inventive than the class of 2016. We are your neighbors, relatives, customers, future employees, and maybe complete strangers, but we are friends. We are the supportive voices of the future, and we need your help.What is Junior Journey?The mission of the Junior Journey is to involve CBHS juniors in a one-week, cross-cultural learning experience that will expand students’ sense of both their world and who they are through service and adventure learning. Previous CBHS students and staff have travelled to Biloxi, Mississippi and Almost Heaven, West Virginia to document the journeys of residents whose lives have been impacted by the BP Oil Spill and Hurricane Katrina, as well as participating in service projects with Habitat for Humanity to help rebuild their communities. This year, over the week of April 12-18, the class of 2016 is going to Rockaway, New York, a community that was devastated by Hurricane Sandy and is still in the process of rebuilding itself. In addition to this service project, juniors will learn how to tell powerful stories through documentary in a process that includes interviewing area residents from our Expeditionary Learning partner school in Red Hook, New York and compiling oral histories to draw on and learn from the life experiences of others. Former Junior Journey participants say: “Although I am only 18, Junior Journey is, and I believe will always be, one of the most influential and life changing moments of my life.”“Seeing the inside of her [the interviewee’s] home was very humbling to me, but knowing that the rain won't leak through her ceiling because of the roof that I helped build for her is very inspiring.”“I always took my class for granted before, but now I realize just how amazing and unique each and every individual who was on the experience with me truly is.” Why do we need money?Buses, shelter, food... story:
The team 

Allow me start by introducing the team behind the NEW Jericho Orphanage Home. It currently consists of three members:

Kabalo, 29, Tanzania. Kabalo is the founder and coordinator of Jericho Orphanage Home .
Lara, 22, Iceland. Volunteer. Responsible for budget, income and expenses. Lara has worked with Kabalo for 6 months helping out with the children and started planning the new orphanage with him.
Emilie, 19, Denmark. Volunteer. Newcomer and touched by the initiative and big hearts of Kabalo - and initiator of this crowdfunding

The Jericho Orphanage Home is a licensed Orphanage founded by Kabalo in 2010. It presently hosts 18 children aged 7 – 15. Kabalo was 23 when he took a private initiative to help the first, small child in 2008. Now there are 18 children that Kabalo and we volunteers take care of – and not space enough in the old house, which is only 90 sqm (three rooms).

Kabalo's mission

Kabalo's mission is to give children the same chance as he got, when his father died. He was 12 and brought to an Orphanage. Deeply grateful for the care and education he got there, he has made it his mission to help children, empower them and coach them to become productive members of society. He believes this is done through rehabilitation, education and teaching them selfreliance skills. 

To absorb knowledge, however, you have to have a secure base - a functioning home, and that is why this project is so important to us. The future of our children depends on it.

Kabalo's story: Why the Jericho Orphanage was founded

If you have watched the video, you will already know about Kabalo and his past.  If not, then here is a story that will touch your hearts:
Kabalo is 29 years old. He is educated veterinarian, and his former job was tutoring vet students in college. Kabalo lost his father when he was 12 years old, and due to their economy, the mother had to send Kabalo to an orphanage. The orphanage took care of him, and is the reason, that he was able to attend school and get an education. The tutoring gave a good salary, but Kabalo wished to pay back to community in gratitude for the chance he had been given.
When Kabalo was 22 years old, he took in his first orphaned kid, James. James was 6 years and albino – as were his parents. Some people in Tanzania believe that if you kill an albino, you will receive luck and fortune, and James had lost both his parents to this belief.
The second child that entered Kabalo's home was Neema, 9 years old. Both her parents had died of HIV and she was left without anyone else.
The number of children increased, and the government advised Kabalo to get an orphanage permit. He recieved the permit in 2010, when he was 25 years old, and that marked the beginning of Jericho Orphanage home.
Kabalo now had a home full of kids he had to take care of, and it did not work out with a full time job. He decided to sacrifice his job and dedicated himself 100% to the children.
He now had two rents to pay (his own house and the house where the children lived) plus food, clothes, books, school etc. for the kids, and no job. To get a bit of an income, he decided to grow crops to sell and live from. As the years passed by, the number of kids kept increasing and we house 18 kids at the moment.


The NEW Jericho Orphanage Home

Kabalo took a big decision in 2014 and sold his car to buy a piece of land outside the city, where a new and better orphanage home is being built.

Since Kabalo owns the land, the new orphanage will not have to pay rent and more of the little resources we have, can be used for taking care of the children – so they can get better food and have the things they need to attend school.

The new orphanage home will have better of space and make it possible for everybody, kids, volunteers and Kabalo to stay with each others 24/7. It is modest in western terms – but for us and the children a big improvement.

It is situated outside the city with open fields and a big garden and we are planning also to have some domestic animals, such as cows and chickens, and make a vegetable garden on the estate to teach the kids how to be selfprovided.

We wish to make our orphanage more attractive to volunteers who want to explore another culture and way of living, and at the same time do something great for those who need it. Therefore the new orphanage will also provide improved accomodation for our volunteers from all around the world.

We want to give our children a second chance. Many of them grew up on the streets with nobody to take care of them or help them through life. They have faced challenges and situations, that no child should ever have to be near, and we believe more than anything, that these kids deserve a new chance in life. That is why we wish to create a safe environment for our kids, so they can focus their energy on studying and not on surviving. 

A project like this costs money, and that is something that few has enough of here. We therefore ask for your help.


What we need & what you get

We need 17.000 dollars to cover all the building expenses. Of this money 14.000 dollars provide us with bricks, cement, wood, stones, water.
3.000 dollars cover toilet, sink, doors and windows. Payment to the workers are included.

We are presently funding the building with our own little supplies and hope to move all children in March 2015.

Are you in doubt of whether you want to contribute or not? - Here are some numbers to take into consideration:

If we reach more than our goal, the spare money will provide clothes, food, books, inventory, education and entertainment for the children.

All kids go to school - and here is how big a difference very little can do:

-  A full school uniform - 14 USD

-  School books for one child - 1,50 USD

-  Food for a day (three meals) - 3,50 USD

-  School, pr child for 6 months - 4 USD

Little can mean a lot.
For many years Kabalo has spent all his time and money to care for the kids.

Let’s give the New Jericho Orphanage Home even better possibilities to raise and empower these children.

As a token of our gratitude for supporting our project and helping our children, we will love to send you pictures, stories, drawings and videos from the children and us.
(Please note: We hoped, that we would get your email automatically through Indiegogo, but we were wrong. We really want to share the procedure with you, so to get your perk, please email buyombo@gmail.com or post at our facebook page with your name and the perk you claimed. Thank you!)

Other ways to help

Our main goal is to build our orphanage, but we understand, that money can sometimes be a problem (trust us, that is our main problem), and if you wish to help, then money shouldn't stop you.

We will gladly receive anything you can think of such as blankets, clothes, toys, books, bags, pencils or anything.
Our post box is:
P.O. Box 11134
Meru Posta Arusha Tanzania

It would also be a great help, if you spread the word of our project. Share it with all your family and friends!

And at last - if funding, pictures and a big THANK YOU! isn't enough, if you want to visit us in Karatu, Tanzania and work with our amazing children, then please, volunteer and come! 

Thank you for your interest and contribution!
Kabalo, Lara, Emilie and all the children at Jericho Orphanage Home.

story:
The Rundown

I'm Adam Nicholson. I'm a writer and artist, teacher, and community arts organizer, and I am launching a project to help artists connect with each other and the world, hone their skills, and make an independent living doing what they love.

Enter Sala Creative Association.


(Sala, to its friends)

Sala is designed to help musicians, writers, visual and performing artists, and creatives of all types place and sell their work; find employers, clients, and patrons; connect with other creatives in their field and all fields; develop professionally; master their craft; and engage in arts discourse.

I come from Springfield, Illinois, a city of amazing creative energy in the heart of so-called "flyover country." Springfield, like most places on Earth, is somewhat removed from major metropolitan creative centers, but in the twenty-first century, distance should be a trivial concern. And talent lives everywhere. As an association, Sala will be based online, connecting creatives from Springfield to Paris to everywhere with contacts and resources from all over, as well aswith each other — and in doing so, will connect great creative work to the world.

I am currently talking with web developers and planning the buildout of a powerful website collecting creative development, marketing, and networking resources in one place. Sala's Indiegogo campaign is live now, and with complete funding, the website should be ready for early access later this year and general availability by early 2016.

I see potential energy that I want to help turn into kinetic energy. I have known successful artists, and I have also known talented and ambitious artists with no strong sense for what steps to take after the creative work is done. Many of the most creative people aren’t always equipped for the "left brain" business of making a living from their creative work.

Meanwhile, the creative landscape is changing. Whereas before, gatekeepers like galleries, labels, and publishers presented something of an obstacle to artists — especially those with unique talents and visions outside the mainstream — today, with the right help and tools, creatives can be masters of their own destiny. Sala seeks to ensure creatives get those tools and that help.

It all starts with a website: a space where creatives can sell and showcase their work; build and host professional CVs and portfolios; seek out paying work and have work seek them; learn from the best and lend their own unique expertise and perspective in the areas they know and love. I hope you'll help make this all possible by giving to the cause at igg.me/at/sala and spreading the word. With your support, Sala will help to make creative work a more viable living, and help creativity live!

Why?

There are many professional associations, development resources, networking services for independent creatives, but few organizations offer all of these benefits together. Fewer still serve creatives in every field, from design and visual art to music, to the performing arts, to video, to writing and beyond. And perhaps none do all of this affordably, online. Except Sala.
In the twenty-first century, the creative world is experiencing a renaissance, perhaps a revolution. Crowdfunding, social networking, affordable print/produce-on-demand solutions, subscription models for creative and productivity applications, and other developments, gatekeepers like galleries, labels, and publishing houses are diminishing in importance; independent creatives are more empowered as masters of their own destiny; and professional associations and services can and must be even more accessible and powerful than ever before.
Existing arts and services websites are not keeping pace with the full range of available possibilities for communication and connection, and in many cases are coasting, content to provide or report the same information about the same artists, fairs, and shows by the same old world gatekeepers. And professional associations — the type you might include on your resume — are hardly keeping pace with the Internet, providing services almost exclusively at expensive destination conferences and conventions, leaving even those who can afford to travel to fend for themselves the other fifty-one weeks of the year.
Sala will put independent creatives of all types directly in touch with all of the contacts, leads, tools, and professional resources they need to succeed, using the most current and powerful delivery methods available, at all times, accessibly and affordably.

What Is Sala? What Does It Do?

Sala is a professional association whose mission to enhance the economic viability of independent creatives; foster creative expression and artistic excellence; and expand public awareness, appreciation, and patronage of creative work by providing member creatives with community, opportunities, resources, and support. Among the specific benefits offered are:
  • A public-facing gallery and online storefront for member art, music, writing, and more in digital and material formats.
  • Continually updated listings of commissions, gigs, calls for artists and submissions, and opportunities for employment and collaboration.
  • Online professional profiles, where member creatives can build and manage organized CVs and portfolios of their work.
  • Up-to-date news, essays, talks, and panel discussions about contemporary happenings and ideas in creative industry and academia.
  • And more!
Sala is also a member-curated space. While all of the above benefits and services will be actively created, maintained, and updated by the organization, additionally, member creatives will be enabled and encouraged to create and host their own content while boosting and tagging other user-generated content to help each other easily find the resources that are most helpful, interesting, and relevant at any moment.

How Does This Work?

Sala Creative Association will not accept advertising. Membership will be by subscription at the affordable rate of $5 per month.
The goal of this campaign is to raise $25,000 for registration of Sala as an organization with all appropriate regulatory agencies, and design, development, and launch of the Sala website. Any and all funds raised beyond this goal will go toward improvement of site design and features, and underwriting Sala's first year of operation.

How Can I Help?

  • Share this page! More views from more places means better ranking and visibility on Indiegogo and a greater potential for success.
  • Tell your friends about Sala and why you think it's great! Follow us on Facebook and Twitter, share our updates, and invite others to do the same.
  • And of course, if you have some tips for ensuring the success of this campaign or other support to offer, I'm happy to hear from you in the comments here at Indiegogo or via email at nicholson@salacreative.org.
With your help, creative work becomes a viable living!
