And more!

Sala is also a member-curated space. While all of the above benefits and services will be actively created, maintained, and updated by the organization, additionally, member creatives will be enabled and encouraged to create and host their own content while boosting and tagging other user-generated content to help each other easily find the resources that are most helpful, interesting, and relevant at any moment.How Does This Work?Sala Creative Association will not accept advertising. Membership will be by subscription at the affordable rate of $5 per month.The goal of this campaign is to raise $25,000 for registration of Sala as an organization with all appropriate regulatory agencies, and design, development, and launch of the Sala website. Any and all funds raised beyond this goal will go toward improvement of site design and features, and underwriting Sala's first year of operation.
How Can I Help?
 
Share this page! More views from more places means better ranking and visibility on Indiegogo and a greater potential for success.
Tell your friends about Sala and why you think it's great! Follow us on Facebook and Twitter, share our updates, and invite others to do the same.
And of course, if you have some tips for ensuring the success of this campaign or other support to offer, I'm happy to hear from you in the comments here at Indiegogo or via email at nicholson@salacreative.org.

With your help, creative work becomes a viable living!

story:
Short Summary

Help fund my college fees this coming year for my MPhil in Archaeology at Cambridge University and contribute to disentangling the complicated consequences of centuries of colonialism among the Guaiquerí people on Margarita Island, Venezuela. Along the way help create what could become the longest thesis acknowledgments ever!

I have proposed the record "Longest Thesis Acknowledgments Ever" to the Guinness World Records and the application is currently being processed. The only other record of a similar nature was made by Krishna Nand Sharma who wrote 3,555 words of acknowledgments in his book in 2012 and holds an unofficial record. Be a part of this project and help me break this record by setting an official Guinness Record! Keep checking back to this page to find out more as I'll be posting updates about the status of the record.

About me

My name is Oliver Antczak and I am both Venezuelan and Polish. With a passion for archaeology, especially in my troubled home of Venezuela, and the Caribbean at large, I have dedicated my bachelor’s thesis as well as my upcoming Master's to the Guaiquerí ethnic group from Margarita Island in Venezuela. I spent my youth in Venezuela, graduating from Colegio Interacional de Caracas in 2013 with an IB diploma. In 2016, I finished a BA in Human Interaction, with a minor in Archaeology at Leiden University College, in The Hague. Since 2016 I have been a researcher associated to the Unidad de Estudios Arqueologicos, Universidad Simon Bolivar, Venezuela. This year I got accepted into Cambrige and Oxford for a MPhil in Archaeology, and I've picked Cambridge due to it being a 1 year program, and the faculty and program being better. Please help me  go to Cambridge University and continue this research!

My Research

My research thus far has focused on the relationship between ethnic identity and material culture among the Guaiquerí ethnic group of Margarita Island, Venezuela. Due to heavy mixing with the Spanish invaders in the early colonial period, the Guaiquerí have ostensibly lost all material connection with their pre-colonial ancestors. This could be a harrowing case for identity formation considering that material culture has been deemed fundamental to the development of collective identities, however, Guaiqueríes maintain a strong ethnic identity, expressed most notably in political organizations on the island. Therefore, my research question is:  do the Guaiqueríes have material culture which they identify with? And based on the answer to that question: What is the Guaiquerí identity based on? The case of the Guaiqueríes has already been cursorily explored in my BA thesis, but requires comparison with other case studies as well as more work on Margarita before any definitive conclusions can be reached.

For my BA thesis, I conducted two seasons of interviews and museum studies on Margarita in the attempt to establish if Guaiqueríes indeed had lost material continuity with their pre-colonial ancestors, and if so, what effect this had on their identity formation. I was initially introduced into the community by anthropologist Ayala Lafée-Wilbert, who has pioneered work among and authored important books about the little known Guaiqueríes[1] , particularly from the community in El Poblado, Porlamar, Margarita. I began by identifying the specific aspects which make up their identity (territory, physiognomy, language, traditions, matriarchy, etc.) and attempted to identify the role that material culture (or its lack thereof) plays in their identity formation. Initial results support the hypothesis that material culture is lacking, if not absent, from Guaiquerí identity formation. I speculate that the fervent adoration of the Virgen del Valle—a catholic image of Mary brought to Margarita in the early 16th Century—is in fact the strongest and one of the few remaining legacies of pre-colonial Guaiqueríes.

Much more research must be conducted, and an adequate theoretical framework should be developed to approach this phenomenon. For my Master's, further interviews and participant observation need to be undertaken, as well as thorough exploration of literature on other ethnic groups in the Caribbean such as the Kalinaga and Garifuna (and other phenomena such as the Virgen de Guadalupe and the Virgen del Cobre). In the near future, there is also the possibility of new material culture being excavated on Margarita in the wake of ongoing archaeological research. Exploring the introduction of material culture and the rekindling of a material connection to the past for the Guaiqueríes is an opportunity that cannot be overemphasized in terms of understanding heritage, the impacts of colonialism, and the key role that material culture has in identity formation.

My research at Cambridge University will entail more work in the field on Margarita, particularly interviewing Guaiqueríes, as well as collection studies in museums and collections on the island. Future aspects of the project will also involve documentary research at archives (the AGN in Caracas, and the AGI in Seville for example) to explore the written past of the Guaiqueríes and determine possible continuities in material culture from texts. An important community aspect is also planned, in the form of informative written and audiovisual materials that will be designed for the community’s different age groups (adults and schoolchildren), the inhabitants of Margarita Island at large as well as visiting tourists. I plan to also conduct workshops uncovering other vestiges of Guaiquerí identity, materially (through archaeological digs) and orally (through focus groups and meetings). Finally, in the further future, I also plan to undertake comparative trans-national work on the Dutch island of Bonaire among the afro-Bonairean inhabitants of the town of Rincón, descendants of 19th-century enslaved salt rakers, to obtain a distinct comparative account of similar processes in the Southeastern Caribbean.

The Impact

The result of this research will be a fresh theoretical approach to understanding post-colonial identities (particularly their relationship to material culture) as well as novel work among the communities of the Southeastern Caribbean in an attempt to understand and manage colonial legacies with these communities themselves. On a local level, the possibility of the discovery and reintroduction of important identifying elements (material, linguistic, memory, etc.) lost throughout the colonization process, the strengthening of ethnic identities, and the potential for community-archaeology projects with ethnic groups in the Southeastern Caribbean are all important facets as well as future paths for this research project.

On a meta-level, a rethinking of key social-science concepts such as culture, identity, and their relationships to material culture, may arise from the controversial idea that ethnic groups can maintain a strong identity while not expressing it materially.

While the anthropological and theoretical findings may be of impact, at the heart of this research are the people who share the data with me, who live a complicated reality, and express their identities uniquely. I will work hand in hand with the communities which are a part of this research in order to retrieve the tools to reintroduce important identity-forming aspects (such as material culture, as well as educational materials) to the people who provide this fascinating case study. As mentioned previously, this will be put into practice through long-term community workshops, as well as the development of educational materials. The ultimate impact of my research will be the strengthening of identity within the communities I study by providing them with multiple means to better understand and deepen their connection to their ancestral legacy.

Risks & Challenges

Venezuela is currently embroiled in a very complicated socio-political crisis. While I fully intend to return to complete this research, the country is very insecure, basic foods can be very difficult to come by, and medication is scarce. I, together with millions of other Venezuelans, hold my breath, hoping and doing as much as possible for a change in the situation. However, there are no guarantees and no timeframe for regime-change, and even less so for an improvement of the situation.

Therefore, the goals and impact of this research are dependent not only on my skills, plans, and abilities, but also on luck and cooperation in Venezuela. There is always risk in Venezuela, and that is something I am used to, having grown up there, however, the situation is dire and reaching a breaking point in recent months. I am currently planning on returning in December 2017, or in 2018, in order to finish the research, but that may become impossible if the situation further escalates. In that case, I plan to turn to Bonaire and the people of Rincón to continue the thesis topic with them before I can return later to the Guaiqueríes.

If you want to help with the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela, you can also contribute here.

What I Need

The amount I am trying to raise comes directly from Cambridge in their student online system.

The costs I need to cover are:

  1. University Composition Fee Home/EU – 10,800 GBP
  2. Student Maintenance - 12,320 GBP
  3. Non-UK Settling in Supplement 350 GBP

Which all adds up to a total of 23,470 GBP which when transferred to Euros becomes 27,703 EU.

The University Composition Fee needs to be paid immediately and is the main priority, however, I need to also be able to show the university that I can pay the 12,320 GBP for maintenance in order to be accepted.

I am not solely relying on this fund to pay my fees since it is possible to take out a loan from the UK government to cover Tuition Fees. The maximum possible loan I can take it 10,280. I fully intend to take such a loan after counting and employing all the funds I receive in this fundraiser.

More information about the loan here.

What You Get

There are various tiers of rewards for contributing to this campaign. They all include you being in my acknowledgments.

*Your name should be a first and last name and should not contain profanities.*

*All perks include your name being listed in the acknowledgments, The higher the perk the more extra you get.*

1 Euros: Name Listed

This means that your name is listed in a group of other names.

Ex. Thank you [Not your name], [Your name], [Not your name]…

5 Euros: Get a Sentence Dedicated to You

You will get an entire sentence about you in my acknowledgments.

Pick from 3 options:

  • Extremely Grateful Sentence

A elaborate sentence with nice adjectives to make you feel fuzzy.

Ex. I need to thank [Your name] for those warm nights by the fire discussing life, this work would be impossible without your strong support and jokes.

  • Reserved Gratitude Sentence

A straightforward, no-nonsense thank you that doesn't go into detail.

Ex. [Your name] was crucial to finishing this work, thank you.

  • Ambiguous Thank You? Sentence

A confusing sentence which leaves you unsure.

Ex. Since being a small boy I’ve been around [Your name] and he has done a lot, good and bad, and I guess I would like to thank him for those times in the hot air balloon.

  • Sarcastic Thanx Sentence

A sentence that clearly doesn’t mean what it literally says

Ex. Thanks [Your name] for always standing over my shoulder and peering into the screen trying to read my work, you are irreplaceable.

10 Euros: Get Called Out

Here you will get called out for having doubted me, or for having made it difficult for me.

Pick between 3 options:

  • Very Aggressive Call Out

No mincing of words, we really dislike each other.

Ex. [Your name], you tried hard to stop me, even publishing fake nudes of me online, but I made it anyways. In your face, don't ever come by my house [Your name].

  • Passive-Aggressive Call Out

We are not friends but I wont go out and say it so clearly. 

Ex. [Your name] wasn't always there for me, but I cannot fault her, she wasn't always very dependable and she has problems of her own.

  • Straightforward Call Out

Ex. You said I wouldn't make it [Your name]. Well check it out, I finished my thesis.

25 Euros: Get a Paragraph Dedicated to You

You will get an entire paragraph (at least 3 sentences) about you in my acknowledgments.

Pick from 4 options:

  • Extremely Grateful Paragraph

A elaborate paragraph with nice adjectives to make you feel fuzzy and goes into more detail than a sentence.

Ex. of one sentence: I need to thank [Your name] for those warm nights by the fire discussing life, this work would be impossible without your strong support.

  • Reserved Gratitude Paragraph

A straightforward, no-nonsense thank you that doesn't go into specifics but carries on for more than a sentence.

Ex. of one sentence: [Your name] was crucial to finishing this work, thank you.

  • Ambiguous Thank You? Paragraph

A confusing paragraph which leaves you unsure and goes into more detail than a sentence.

Ex. of one sentence: Since being a small boy I’ve been around [Your name] and he has done a lot, good and bad, and I guess I would like to thank him for those times in the hot air balloon.

  • Sarcastic Thanx Paragraph

A confusing paragraph which leaves you unsure and goes into more detail than a sentence.

Ex. of one sentence: Thanks [Your name] for always standing over my shoulder and peering into the screen trying to read my work, you are irreplaceable.

50 Euro: Group Acknowledgment

Get together with friends and get thanked all together in a cozy paragraph. You will get an entire paragraph about you in my acknowledgments, with each member being specifically called out and thanked.

  • You can pick between the same 4 choices as the individual paragraphs above.

100 Euro: Amusing Anecdote about You

For this amount you will receive a longer interesting and detailed story just about you.

You can pick between 2 options:

  • Amusing Anecdote

A fun, inspirational and light-hearted story about you and me.

Ex. When I was younger [Your name] helped me build a tree house in our garden. It was a huge tree house, probably 3 stories high and [Your name] did all the heavy lifting and so showed me what hard work can get you. That tree house still stands there today, covered in bird poop and confetti. Inside those rotting walls live the fun memories I shared with [Your name]. Thank you, I hope we make a lot more beautiful memories together.

  • Slightly Creepy Anecdote

Same as above but with slightly creepy aspects that raise a few questions.

Ex. When I was younger [Your name] helped me build a soundproof tree house in our garden. It was a huge tree house, probably 3 stories high and [Your name] did all the heavy lifting and so showed me what hard work can get you. That tree house still stands there to this day, covered in bird poop. Inside those rotting walls live the memories I shared with [Your name]. Thank you, I hope we make a lot more interesting memories together.

500 Euro: Poem

You will get a full length poem written and dedicated just for you (and it will include your name).

Pick between these 4 options:

  • Haiku

A heartfelt haiku with natural themes, that is slightly ambiguous.

  • A Couplet

Actually 4 lines of freely rhyming text that follow a nice syllable scheme. Will be very grateful and colorful.

  • A Limerick

A funny 5-line poem that may contain double-entendres and strange words.

  • Free Verse

A longer poem (6-10 lines) that won’t be restricted by rhyme or rhythm but will contain florid descriptions and tear-jerking confessions.

1000 Euros: Poem and Mailed Thesis

A poem (See above) and a mailed bound version of my completed thesis (in 2018).

Contact me

Do you have any questions? Email me at antczako@gmail.com and I will answer them!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help financially, you can still lay down a block to build this into something real! Please share this with your friends, and help me reach the goal. 

[1] Ayala Lafée-Wilbert, C., & Wilbert, W. (2011). Memoria Histórica de Los Resguardos Guaiqueríes. Caracas: Ediciones IVIC.

story:
Background

1 in 4 people in Lebanon is a Syrian refugee, and 1 in 10 people in Lebanon right now is a Syrian refugee child. There are 528,000 Syrian children that are of school age, and around 321,000 of them are out of school children.

Even though the ministry of education in Lebanon has created remedial programs to help refugees enroll in public schools, the public school system is already at capacity, even with the double shift policy - there is literally no more space -  and is already inadequate and problematic itself to say the least. This is why the work being done by NGOs like the Kayany Foundation is extremely important as it provides an effective and efficient alternative for the majority of school-age refugees to have access to education.

Kayany Malala School, Bekaa, Lebanon

The Impact

We believe that education should be provided in a way to open up more opportunities. It is not about learning just to learn, but rather education should act as a bridge to a brighter future. This is even more crucial when offering education to refugees.

It is not enough to just open up more schools, but what is being taught and how it is being taught makes all the difference in whether education has an impact or not. We believe that to get the most out of education, it is important to teach highly marketable skills that are relevant to current and future trends in the global economy. This is why we are focusing on technology and on having refugees not only acquire but actually become proficient in the various uses of technology in a professional setting. We see this bootcamp as a thorough training in digital literacy and proficiency to build a solid base of digital skills that they can then apply through their education in order to open up future opportunities for them upon graduation.

In order to teach these skills, we are adopting a project-based approach where students will work on group projects centered around a problem that they encounter in their community. By working through the problem and developing their projects, they would be learning different digital skills along the way. We divided them into several modules starting with digital autonomy and citizenship, research skills, to productivity programs such as Microsoft office, data manipulation, multimedia creation, Adobe, and coding using scratch academy as well as web development, with an intro to java and html.

We will also be offering “digital trends” sessions where they will have exposure to the current tech trends shaping our future like google cardboard, virtual reality, 3D printing, app development, and robotics among others. At the same time, we will also be hosting guest workshops with other local startups and social enterprises to cover topics like women empowerment and entrepreneurship, sustainability and recycling, and art, animation, and design.

The program will culminate with a final day celebration where students will present their projects to guests including their parents, Kayany, the American University of Beirut, and municipal/ ministry officials, as well as receive Microsoft Digital Literacy Certificates.

Who We Are 

Jehane Akiki | ioi : With the onset of the Syrian civil war, my home country of Lebanon became the country with the highest concentration of refugees in the world. As I was doing my Masters in International Affairs at The New School in NYC, I felt this incessant duty to give back and so I turned to the field of design thinking two years ago to try and find durable solutions for the Syrian refugee crisis. This led me to focus on education and through this work, I met the team behind Kayany Foundation’s GHATA schools, specifically Rabih Shibli and Hala Fleihan from the American University of Beirut’s Center for Civic Engagement and Community Service who work closely with the NGO and are responsible for the conception and the design of the school and Lamia Masri from the Kayany Foundation itself. All of this culminated in me designing a systemic strategy for effective education provision in order to help refugees gain resilience and slowly overcome their refugee status. Having this big picture together led me to then put this digital literacy summer bootcamp together for Kayany Foundation as well as start ioi, a strategic design and development consulting agency, after realizing the value in - and need for - merging the two fields. Learn more at http://www.ioistrategicdesign.com

Kayany Foundation: a non-profit organization founded with the mission to provide free education and support services to Syrian refugees in Lebanon and the vision to save a generation through education. Kayany partnered with the American University of Beirut and the Lebanese Ministry of Social Affairs to start building portable school campuses (GHATA) in Syrian refugee camps in order to secure access to formal and accredited education for thousands of children in the Bekaa Valley. Kayany also runs two all-girls secondary schools that were developed in partnership with Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala Yousefzai, one of which will be the location of this project. Learn more about their work at http://kayany-foundation.org/

 

Mariam Haidar | Edutek: Mariam’s goal is to create a change in the education sector and build young, confident minds capable of becoming future leaders by providing the space for them to develop their 21st century and STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics) skills. She is the founder of EDUTEK, a newly established social enterprise in the Bekaa in Lebanon, that provides STEAM hands-on projects for children and youth in order to learn while having fun. She decided to start EDUTEK after graduating with a Masters in Management Information systems and Bachelors in Computer Science as a response to the scarce opportunities and resources in the Bekaa due to the centralize nature of Lebanon wherein everything is found in the capital, Beirut. She has 10 years of experience working in the education sector across Lebanon and Syria with different curriculum. Mariam is also the Bekaa Area Manager at Digital Opportunity Trust (DOT) Lebanon and she is continuously enriching her technical and managerial skills, learning opportunities, and networks and has partaken in multiple programs such as Arab Women Entrepreneur Program 2015; Tech Women USA; and is the ambassador for Technovation in Lebanon. Learn more at www.edutekonline.com

E. Adam Attia: E. Adam Attia is a New-York based artist who addresses sociopolitical issues, especially related to warfare, with his work, and who is collaborating on developing the art therapy portion of the boot camp. Adam became drawn to this space after serving for a brief period in the US Military and then studying fine arts, the combination of which inspired him to use his art to communicate the tragedies of war to the world through the child’s perspective. As the art therapy sessions will be administered by a local art therapist/ clinical psychologist, Adam will work after the completion of the bootcamp on creating his own artwork based on the work of the students during the art therapy sessions in order to raise awareness on the general effects of warfare on children and share their stories with a wider audience in an exhibition that will be held later on in NYC. Learn more about his work on http://www.eadamattia.com

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk is Internet and connectivity problems as it is an area-wide problem in the Bekaa, but we are working on overcoming such a hurdle by preparing offline modules that would only need minimal syncing and will be using the Internet only when needed.

Another risk would be to have low attendance; however, since this program is being administered with their school and is using their regular modes of transportation, we are confident that it should not be problematic.

How You Can Help

Please help us reach our goal by donating whatever you can afford - every little bit counts. The money you donate will go towards covering our expenses which include the salaries of qualified trainers and art therapist, secure transportation of the trainers and the students, materials, art supplies, and food. In addition, it will help us cover the 8% processing fees that Indiegogo charges on the money we raise here.

We want you to be as engaged as possible in the different stages of this campaign and throughout the project itself. With our rewards, we hope to capture this synergy and create a link between you and the students who will be using the skills they acquire throughout the bootcamp to give back to you as a thank you for making the program happen.

 

Other Ways To Help

We would also appreciate your help in getting the word out: please share this page with as many people as you can on social media to help us spread the word and follow us on Facebook and Instagram to stay updated with the progress of the project.
story_txt: Background1 in 4 people in Lebanon is a Syrian refugee, and 1 in 10 people in Lebanon right now is a Syrian refugee child. There are 528,000 Syrian children that are of school age, and around 321,000 of them are out of school children.Even though the ministry of education in Lebanon has created remedial programs to help refugees enroll in public schools, the public school system is already at capacity, even with the double shift policy - there is literally no more space -  and is already inadequate and problematic itself to say the least. This is why the work being done by NGOs like the Kayany Foundation is extremely important as it provides an effective and efficient alternative for the majority of school-age refugees to have access to education.Kayany Malala School, Bekaa, LebanonThe ImpactWe believe that education should be provided in a way to open up more opportunities. story:
In 1994 the Sons of Confederate Veterans placed a Southern Cross of Honor on the Mississippi grave of Silas Chandler, a black man.

By honoring Silas, the SCW helped transform a hazy story about an obscure slave into a full-blown legend. Films, prints, photos and T-shirts soon followed, all promoting him as a loyal son of the South who became a Confederate soldier, heroically battling Yankees alongside his white owner. High lighting Silas' military career is a way of suggesting that Southern blacks were just as eager as whites to fight back against the invaders. It is a position consistent with the belief that the war did not ignite over slavery but over predatory Northern acts.

The discovery of a letter from newly inaugurated President Abraham Lincoln to the governor of Florida has generated renewed interest in Lincoln's views toward slavery.

The letter, found at the Lehigh County Historical Society in Allentown, Pennsylvania, is a form letter from Lincoln to Governor Madison S. Perry transmitting "an authenticated copy of a Joint Resolution to amend the Constitution of the United States." On March 16, 1861, Lincoln sent the same letter to all of the governors of the states, including states that had already seceded from the Union and formed their own confederate government. What was the Corwin Amendment and what was Lincoln's role in its attempted ratification.

Lincoln was telling the South, "Just come back to the union and you can keep your slaves forever.” Lincoln was going into panic mode with all that cotton money walking away, one state at a time. What we were told in school, that the Civil War was over slavery, is an outright lie.

The Cross of Honor, created in 1900 by the United Daughters of the Confederacy, was intended for Confederates who performed acts of valor on the battlefield, and the award was recently bestowed on soldiers descended from Confederate veterans. So what role did Silas and other slaves really play in the war, and why did he choose to fight for the South?

One thing is clear. Ever since the SCV posthumously honored Silas, a body servant who accompanied his white master into service, accounts of black Confederate troops have surged in popularity, with some now claiming that upwards of 100,000 blacks fought willingly in Southern ranks.

My name is Gregory Newson i’m an artist/writer and a descendant of former slaves from Jacksonville, Florida, my mother migrated north where i was born in New York’s Harlem Hospital. I started drawing and painting in a racially charge atmosphere at age nine way before I could read or write.

I hope what artist’s do is clear to everyone;  We embrace and bring attention to a subject or provoke thought. My journey started back when I did a painting of a black Confederate soldier from pure imagination that instigated a conversations from my Afro-American friends, they voiced an opinion; “Southern slaves were just stupid like (Stepin Fetchit)”. I realized at that moment, there opinion was Influenced by grammar school education, media and Hollywood's portrayal of Southern negroes.

But it was the word "Stupid" that disturb me the most as my community embrace the phrase Black Power, I was compelled to seek out a few historians which ignited a passionate search for clarity; “Who was the black Confederates?”

As I pondered the black Confederate soldier in my future study and paintings, I realized this subject had a therapeutic effect on me, I stop feeling like a victim, It was no boogeyman around the corner stopping me from being my own self superhero; No longer was I hearing the cattle call to participate in riots and American historical vandalisms.

Just learning about Anthony Johnson the first registered rich black slave owner in America and the Barbary Wars, where 1.5 million white Christians were held in authentic slavery by Africans blew my mind.

After self publishing, marketing my first book at Civil War reenactments and art shows “Uncle T and the Uppity Spy” attracted hundreds of people thanking me for shedding light on a forbidden history, And surprisingly i was invited to schools to speak about the black Confederates.

I need your help launching my next book named “The wizard and his black hands” it’s about Nathan Bedford Forrest from adolescent to military leader, Fort Pillow and Involvement with reconstruction Klu Klux Klan not the KKK we know today, it's remarkable how much is left out of our education about this American Patriot.  And as someone “me” that was born in a racially-charged environment which did Influence me to hang around the Black Panther Party, I know how Nathan Bedford Forrest’s environment influenced his early life.  I need your financial support to print a 32 page hardcover Y/A edition full color book and to market it to home study families and beyond. They are groups out there that's poorly educated about the Confederacy and Southern people.

I probably cannot do anything to stop historical vandalism,  but with your help we can at least educate the ones that's missing this forbidden history before they become leaders of tomorrow.

P.S. Long Live H. K. Edgerton

story:
„Liberalizam“ je čuveno djelo velikog ekonomiste i liberalnog mislioca Ludwiga von Misesa napisano u odbranu slobodnog društva, te jedno od posljednih djela stare liberalne škole iz kojeg možemo mnogo toga naučiti o liberalnoj ideologiji. Ova knjiga  već više od 80 godina smatra se jednim od najvažnijih liberalnih testamenata za slobodarske pokrete širem svijeta. Ipak, o intelektualnoj klimi koja vlada u zemljama bivše Jugoslavije slikovito svjedoči činjenica da ni gotovo 3 decenije nakon sloma komunizma ova knjiga još uvijek nije prevedena ni na jedan od južnoslavenskih jezika.

Stoga, portal Liberal.hr iz Hrvatske i organizacija Liberalni forum iz Bosne i Hercegovine pokreću zajedničku akciju prikupljanja sredstava za prevod ovog veličanstvenog djela velikog liberalnog mislioca na hrvatski i bosanski jezik. Ako ste ljubitelj slobode i želite dati svoj doprinos širenju i osnaživanju ideja klasičnog liberalizma i slobodne ekonomije u vašoj zemlji, ili ste naprosto zainteresovani za učenje i razvoj tržišta ideja, pozivamo Vas da donirate sredstva i omogućite nam da prevedemo ovo veliko Misesovo djelo.
 

O knjizi:  

 

Objavljena 1927. godine, u jeku rasta popularnosti kolektivističkih ideologija komunizma i fašizma, knjiga postavlja ključno pitanje: ako ne socijalizam i ako ne fašizam ili intervencionizam, koja vrsta društvenog sistema najviše doprinosi ljudskom napretku i prosperitetu? Misesov odgovor sumiran je u naslovu, a podrazumijeva klasični liberalizam.

S ovom knjigom Mises čini više od obnavljanja klasične doktrine. On nudi uvjerljiv temelj za odbranu slobode kojim ispravlja greške koju su prethodno činili predstavnici klasično liberalne škole, tako što ideju slobode ukorjenjuje u instituciji privatnog vlasništva (pitanje oko kojeg je klasična škola povremeno bila nejasna). U sljedećem Misesovom citatu ogleda se golem doprinos toj ideji:

„Program liberalizma, stoga, kada bi se sažeo u jednu riječ, trebao bi se čitati kao: vlasništvo, odnosno privatno vlasništvo nad sredstvima za proizvodnju... Svi drugi zahtjevi liberalizma proizlaze iz ovog temeljnog principa“.  

No, tu je još sjajnih ideja o politikama i rješenjima na kojima treba graditi slobodno društvo. Mises argumentira da je decentralizacija vlasti najbolji recept za mir i političku slobodu. Što se tiče religije, zagovara potpuno odvajanje države i crkve. Po pitanju imigracije, favorizira slobodu kretanja. U pogledu kulture on uzdiže toleranciju. Po pitanju obrazovanja: državna kontrola nad njim mora prestati, i to potpuno.

On se u knjizi iskreno bavi i problemom nacionalizma, te nudi uzdudljivu odbranu racionalizma kao osnovnog temelja liberalnog političkog poretka. Također razmatra i pitanja političke strategije i odnosa liberalizma sa specijalnim političkim interesima.

Ovo je jedna od najvažnijih Misesovih knjiga i također jedna od najispirativnijih knjiga o ideji slobode ikad napisanih. Ostaje jedna od onih knjiga koje u svijetu mogu poslužiti kao iskra za paljenje vatre slobode, što je vjerovatno razlog zašto je već prevedena na mnoštvo svjetskih jezika.

„Liberalism“  is Mises's classic statement in defense of a free society, one of the last statements of the old liberal school and a text from which we can continue to learn. It has been the conscience of a global movement for liberty for 80 years. Nevertheless, the intellectual climate that governs the countries of the former Yugoslavia is portrayed by the fact that almost 3 decades after the fall of communism this book has not yet been translated into any of the South Slavic languages.

Therefore, portal Liberal.hr from Croatia and the organization Liberal Forum from Bosnia and Herzegovina are launching a crowdfunding action to collect funds to translate this magnificent piece from the great liberal thinker into the Croatian and Bosnian language. If you are a lover of freedom and want to contribute to spreading and empowering the ideas of classical liberalism and free economy in your country, or simply are interested in learning and developing the market of ideas, we invite you to donate funds and allow us to translate this great work of Ludwig von Mises.

 

About the book

 

It first appeared in 1927, as a follow-up to both his devastating 1922 book showing that socialism would fail and his 1926 book on interventionism.

It was written to address the burning question: if not socialism, and if not fascism or interventionism, what form of social arrangements are most conducive to human flourishing? Mises's answer is summed up in the title, by which he meant classical liberalism.

Mises did more than restate classical doctrine. He gave a thoroughly modern defense of freedom, one that corrected the errors of the old liberal school by rooting the idea of liberty in the institution of private property (a subject on which the classical school was sometimes unclear). Here is the grand contribution of this volume.

The program of liberalism, therefore, if condensed into a single word, would have to read: property, that is, private ownership of the means of production... All the other demands of liberalism result from this fundamental demand.

But there are other insights too. He shows that political decentralization is the best means to peace and political liberty. As for religion, he recommends the complete separation of church and state. On immigration, he favors the freedom of movement. On culture, he praised the political virtue of tolerance. On education: state involvement must end, and completely.

He deals frankly with the nationalities problem and provides a stirring defense of rationalism as the essential foundation of liberal political order. He discusses political strategy and the relationship of liberalism to special-interest politics.

In some ways, this is the most political of Mises's treatises, and also one of the most inspiring books ever written on the idea of liberty. It remains the book that can set the world on fire for freedom, which is probably why it has been translated into more than a dozen languages.

Ako ste ljubitelj slobode i želite dati svoj doprinos širenju i osnaživanju ideja klasičnog liberalizma i slobodne ekonomije u vašoj zemlji, ili ste naprosto zainteresovani za učenje i razvoj tržišta ideja, pozivamo Vas da donirate sredstva i omogućite nam da prevedemo ovo veliko Misesovo djelo. 
O knjizi:   Objavljena 1927. godine, u jeku rasta popularnosti kolektivističkih ideologija komunizma i fašizma, knjiga postavlja ključno pitanje: ako ne socijalizam i ako ne fašizam ili intervencionizam, koja vrsta društvenog sistema najviše doprinosi ljudskom napretku i prosperitetu? Misesov odgovor sumiran je u naslovu, a podrazumijeva klasični liberalizam.S ovom knjigom Mises čini više od obnavljanja klasične doktrine. On nudi uvjerljiv temelj za odbranu slobode kojim ispravlja greške koju su prethodno činili predstavnici klasično liberalne škole, tako što ideju slobode ukorjenjuje u instituciji privatnog vlasništva (pitanje oko kojeg je klasična škola povremeno bila nejasna). U sljedećem Misesovom citatu ogleda se golem doprinos toj ideji:„Program liberalizma, stoga, kada bi se sažeo u jednu riječ, trebao bi se čitati kao: vlasništvo, odnosno privatno vlasništvo nad sredstvima za proizvodnju... Svi drugi zahtjevi liberalizma proizlaze iz ovog temeljnog principa“.  No, tu je još sjajnih ideja o politikama i rješenjima na kojima treba graditi slobodno društvo. Mises argumentira da je decentralizacija vlasti najbolji recept za mir i političku slobodu. Što se tiče religije, zagovara potpuno odvajanje države i crkve. Po pitanju imigracije, favorizira slobodu kretanja. U pogledu kulture on uzdiže toleranciju. Po pitanju obrazovanja: državna kontrola nad njim mora prestati, i to potpuno.On se u knjizi iskreno bavi i problemom nacionalizma, te nudi uzdudljivu odbranu racionalizma kao osnovnog temelja liberalnog političkog poretka. Također razmatra i pitanja političke strategije i odnosa liberalizma sa specijalnim političkim interesima.Ovo je jedna od najvažnijih Misesovih knjiga i također jedna od najispirativnijih knjiga o ideji slobode ikad napisanih. Ostaje jedna od onih knjiga koje u svijetu mogu poslužiti kao iskra za paljenje vatre slobode, što je vjerovatno razlog zašto je već prevedena na mnoštvo svjetskih jezika.„Liberalism“  is Mises's classic statement in defense of a free society, one of the last statements of the old liberal school and a text from which we can continue to learn. It has been the conscience of a global movement for liberty for 80 years. Nevertheless, the intellectual climate that governs the countries of the former Yugoslavia is portrayed by the fact that almost 3 decades after the fall of communism this book has not yet been translated into any of the South Slavic languages.Therefore, portal Liberal.hr from Croatia and the organization Liberal Forum from Bosnia and Herzegovina are launching a crowdfunding action to collect funds to translate this magnificent piece from the great liberal thinker into the Croatian and Bosnian language. If you are a lover of freedom and want to contribute to spreading and empowering the ideas of classical liberalism and free economy in your country, or simply are interested in learning and developing the market of ideas, we invite you to donate funds and allow us to translate this great work of Ludwig von Mises. About the book It first appeared in 1927, as a follow-up to both his devastating 1922 book showing that socialism would fail and his 1926 book on interventionism.It was written to address the burning question: if not socialism, and if not fascism or interventionism, what form of social arrangements are most conducive to human flourishing? Mises's answer is summed up in the title, by which he meant classical liberalism.Mises did more than restate classical doctrine. He gave a thoroughly modern defense of freedom, one that corrected the errors of the old liberal school by rooting the idea of liberty in the institution of private property (a subject on which the classical school was sometimes unclear). Here is the grand contribution of this volume.The program of liberalism, therefore, if condensed into a single word, would have to read: property, that is, private ownership of the means of production... All the other demands of liberalism result from this fundamental demand.But there are other insights too. He shows that political decentralization is the best means to peace and political liberty. As for religion, he recommends the complete separation of church and state. On immigration, he favors the freedom of movement. On culture, he praised the political virtue of tolerance. On education: state involvement must end, and completely.He deals frankly with the nationalities problem and provides a stirring defense of rationalism as the essential foundation of liberal political order. He discusses political strategy and the relationship of liberalism to special-interest politics.In some ways, this is the most political of Mises's treatises, and also one of the most inspiring books ever written on the idea of liberty. It remains the book that can set the world on fire for freedom, which is probably why it has been translated into more than a dozen languages.

story:
What is Amal ou Salam?

Project Amal ou Salam, meaning Project Hope and Peace in Arabic, is a non-political grassroots organization that works with Syrian refugee children in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon as well as children in Syria to empower the future leaders of Syria through education, intervention and trauma-based care. 

We developed an innovative educational approach that seeks to empower the future leaders of Syria. The core tenets of the approach include working to ensure that every child has the right to an education, a childhood free from trauma and violence, and the hope of a peaceful tomorrow. Project Amal ou Salam has a successful track record of delivering this approach in week-long workshops in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan with volunteers from around the world, in the school that it funds in Jordan and in its community and educational partnerships in Turkey, Lebanon and Syria. 

Our Origins

While visiting an IDP camp in Syria in 2013, Co-Founders Nousha Kabawat and Aziz Abu Sarah were struck by the bored children mirroring the anger, violence and sectarianism around them and began to imagine a grassroots effort to feed the children’s self-esteem and character. With a background in conflict resolution and peacebuilding in post-war societies, Nousha worked to turn her dream of a multicultural, interfaith community into a reality called Project Amal ou Salam.

Free from politics and sectarian dogma, Project Amal ou Salam operates across Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria – few NGOs for Syrian refugee children founded in the past few years are working across borders. 

According to the UNHCR, to date there are 4.8 million registered Syrian refugees, of which more than half are under the age of 17. Since the revolution began in 2011, these children have been forced from their homes and country and have been unable to access basic needs or education. In 2019, children up to eight years old have always had a life of war and conflict. 

Our Impact

Through our workshops, school and community center, Project Amal ou Salam has supported thousands children in four different countries, aided by more than 150 volunteers from around the world.

Project Amal ou Salam Workshops – Jordan and Lebanon

Project Amal ou Salam’s workshops provide open dialogue, giving the kids a safe space to tackle the issues that they face and develop their own ideas and visions for the future of Syria. With activities not present in the refugee camps, our workshops for Syrian refugee children arm them with the tools and confidence to rebuild Syria through art, health, photography, sports and music.

Project Amal ou Salam School – Jarash, Jordan

In Jordan, we have an Amal ou Salam school and community center that plays an important role by filling a gap in the education system: Syrian children were not allowed to enroll in Jordanian schools  for until they were able to pass tests at their appropriate grade level. This gap has left many school aged children at a significant disadvantage to their peers, manifesting in poor grades, difficulty coping with the rigors of a school setting, depression, anxiety, and acting out. 

Before the war, nearly all Syrian children were enrolled in school. Today most Syrian children who are living as refugees in Jordan have been out of school for several years and need significant catch-up time and individualized attention to make up for the hundreds of hours of class time they have missed out on. The Amal ou Salam school prepares students to engage in their new school settings, catch up on the lessons they missed out on and ensures that they can perform as well as their Jordanian peers in their new classrooms.

Since 2017, we've been doing things a little differently! 

Amal ou Salam's popularity and its reach in Jordan has grown! More and more families are knocking on our doors looking for a safe space to grow. We are continuing our regular morning classes for the children not currently attending schools but have also added an afternoon shift for Syrian and Jordanian kids looking to get some extra help with their homework as well as take part in fun activities such as music, arts and sports! Also, we have begun to work with the mothers of the students who have requested English and Arabic lessons. We are so proud that Amal ou Salam has become a hub for entire families to enjoy :) 

NEW for 2019! Project Amal ou Salam book

Thanks to the expertise, talent and hard work of our volunteers, we have designed our own book. With lots of fun activities and original illustrations, this book collects the lessons we taught the children, and those we have learned from them. It talks about Syria, about the world, about our shared humanity, about love, empathy and peace. Want a sneak peek? You can order your e-book now! 

Other Activities

In addition to activities run by Project Amal ou Salam, we have provided material donations (e.g., coloring books, games, sports equipment) and monetary support to schools both within and outside of Syria (Turkey and Lebanon). Additionally, we have supported activities in Idlib, Syria; sent school and art supplies to a refugee camp in Ersal, Lebanon; hosted a football tournament for hundreds of Syrian kids as well as hosted a Ramadan meal for 60 Syrian children and their families in Jordan; and hosted Eid celebrations in Suroui, Turkey for Kurdish refugees who had recently arrived from Kobani, Syria.

Spreading the Word

We are always honored when Project Amal ou Salam is featured in the media because it is a great opportunity for more people to learn about the work that we do. Here are some of our favorite features:

BBC, Syria’s Next Generation, http://goo.gl/SvIGA0

Elle Magazine, Young, Syrian, Female: This Is How you Fight ISIS's Values http://goo.gl/SFeJth

Huffington Post, 6 Organizations Helping Syrian Refugees That You Might Not Have Heard Of, http://goo.gl/Cn1Mwe

National Geographic, Life Through the Lens of Syria’s Uprooted Teens, http://goo.gl/lWktpO

When speaking on a panel at the UN's Global Forum on Youth, Peace and Security, Nousha summarized the issue well when she said: "Syria has become a complex issue but please don't think it is only about violence and killing. Think about the children who need love, attention and caring from everyone around the world so that they become the future generation, not a lost generation."

Impact – Why Your Support is Critical

Providing a safe space for the psycho-social development of Syria’s children is both crucial for the rebuilding and reconciliation processes and for the future of Syrian society, and is more sustainable than direct aid. When PTSD and depression are not treated in children, they result in flashbacks, emotional instability, violent and aggressive behavior, nightmares, isolation and poor academic achievement. Helping the next generation cope with the trauma and tragedy of war will aid them in becoming strong, capable, and productive members of society ready to rebuild their country!

Your donation will go directly towards expanding, building and developing the implementation of Project Amal ou Salam. More specifically, your donation will fund:

The volunteer-run workshops in April 2018 in Jordan for more than 1000 children, aided by 30+ volunteers from all around the world

The Amal ou Salam School and Community Center in Jarash, Jordan

The printing of our book, which will be given to the children attending our workshops.

If you are in the U.S. and would like to make a tax-deductible donation, please make your check or money order out to GreaterGood.org and write “Project Amal ou Salam #65981″ in the memo line. Mail checks to 6262 N Swan Road, Suite 150, Tucson, AZ 85718. You can also make a tax-deductible donation online.

Thank you for your donation!

Keep Spreading the Love <3

story:
Short Summary

      Champion Dreams Productions is not only a Branding, Production and Design company but we are also a lifestyle company as well. We have completed various projects for a variety of individuals and companies while being in business for 6 years. We are looking to raise 1 million dollars in 365 days! A percentage of the funds will be raised for multiple scholarships for the youth. This initiative  is very important to us because it allows us to bless others during our journey plus give back in a major way to be able to assist them with the pursuit of their dreams. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The goal is to raise 1 million dollars in 365 days. 
  • For your donation you will receive a Champion Dreams Collectors Trophy Pin. 

 

The Impact

  • Our fundraising scholarship initiative is very important to us. It enables us to give opportunities to other individuals to be able to capture their dreams through higher learning. 
  • We have never done a fundraising project like this but we believe we will reach our goal with your help!

 

Risks & Challenges

  • This initiative is already a challenge for us because we have never asked for funding before, so the fact that we are asking for your help is a challenge. 
  • We are always up for a challenge and we believe that this 1 Million Dollar goal is a great challenge that we believe that we can achieve. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and we totally understand but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share our campaign with family and friends, other businesses or even your boss.

We have completed various projects for a variety of individuals and companies while being in business for 6 years. We are looking to raise 1 million dollars in 365 days! A percentage of the funds will be raised for multiple scholarships for the youth. What We Need & What You Get

This initiative is already a challenge for us because we have never asked for funding before, so the fact that we are asking for your help is a challenge. 
We are always up for a challenge and we believe that this 1 Million Dollar goal is a great challenge that we believe that we can achieve. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, and we totally understand but that doesn't mean you can't help:
Please share our campaign with family and friends, other businesses or even your boss.
